All resources have an id property that is presently documented as "metadata" - that is, it's a property of every resource that lives outside the resource, not inside it. I propose that we put this back inside the resource.

Background:

In the early drafts of the specification, every resource included an "id" element/property, like so:

<Patient xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
  <id value="[logical-id]"/>

This is the id that is used in the url: GET [base]/Patient/[logical-id]. In doing this, we followed the pattern used by every other RESTful API I've come across, in that the id is right there inside the resource.

At the 2nd connectathon, we observed that the id was basically a duplicate. Whenever you exchange the resource using http or wrap it in atom, the id is duplicated in the envelope, and all any of us were doing is cross-checking it as a sanity check.  So we removed it (a discussion that you can go back and review on the mail list, if you really core. It was a little controversial).

What this means is that if you represent the resource outside an http call, or an atom feed, you need to make your own arrangements for keeping the id (and potentially other metadata) associated with the resource. This is described here: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/resources.html#metadata

Problem

While the current arrangement works, it's unexpected to many implementers. This is a common question for many implementers when they start working with FHIR - where's the id? And the fact that it is not in the resource means that other arrangements have to be made, which makes it more difficult to use FHIR in practice. (Josh ballotted about this for exactly these reasons on the DSTU), but withdrew when he could see that the discussion was going to be complex. However I think we have more broad experience with this and we can have a better discussion now. 

After watching the discussion since we made this decision, and after implementing other RESTful APIs, I've come to the conclusion that we made the wrong decision: while, from a theorist point of view, the id is unncessary, since it is *usually* duplicated, in practice, this is not something where we should deviate from the norm (especially since our rationale applies fully to every other RESTful API, it's not something unique to us)

Hence, I propose to restore the id back into the resource

Notes:
- it would be <id value="[logical-id]"/> in xml, no extensions, and "id" : "logical-id" in JSON. 

- it's mandatory in all contexts except when a resource is submitted as a create operation

- there was this idea that putting the id outside the resource made the resource easier to sign, but that doesn't really work since the id is in resource references

- we currently ban "id" elements from resources, so there's no existing elements to clash with

we use Resource() to describe a reference
to a resource, e.g. on Observation:

subject : Resource(Patient);

This creates 2 uses for the name "Resource" - the name of the base
"Resource" class from which the resources are derived, and the name of
the reference to another resource. The schema and reference
implementations rename the second one to ResourceReference, but this
is a source of confusion for many implementers

So I'm proposing to rename the second use to just "Reference", so it
would be like this:

subject : Reference(Patient);

This name would be used throughout all the specification and the
reference implementations

Here is a quote from section 2.1.19, Paging:

If servers provide paging for the results of a search or history interaction, they SHALL conform to the method described in RFC 5005 (Feed Paging and Archiving) for sending continuation links to the client when returning a bundle (e.g. with history and search). If the server does not do this, there is no way to continue paging. 

RFC5005 has the following in section 1.1 Notational Conventions:

  This specification uses XML Namespaces [3] to uniquely identify XML
   element names.  It uses the following namespace prefix for the
   indicated namespace URI;

   "fh": "http://purl.org/syndication/history/1.0"

However, the FHIR atom schemas do not include that namespace declaration, thus any bundle that actually follows the RFC will be invalid according to the FHIR schemas. Please add that namespace to the schemas when they are generated, as well as the elements called out in the RFC (i.e. <fh:complete/> and <fh:archive/>).

RelatedPerson is limited by the constraint on its relationship to 1 and only 1 Patient. A number of interesting use cases would be opened up if this were changed to allow a RelatedPerson to relate to many Patient resources. The current structure of the RelatedPerson is also limited by defining the Patient and Relationship in seperate properties. By combining these into a single element, multiple relationships can be expressed for a given person.

I've attached a proposed update to the RelatedPerson resource. I've also included an update to the cardinality for name to make it required and to allow for a history of names (similar to Patient).

Use case example 1: A parent can be related to each of his/her children from a single RelatedPerson resource. Same goes for any other person with multiple relationships to patients. As it currently stands, this would require creating n RelatedPerson records for each Patient with a relationship to that person.

Use case example 2: For data interoperability, where FHIR resources may be centralized as reference data for patient matching and record location, custodianship of Patient resources is distributed across members of a data sharing community. In this case, a RelatedPerson resource would be shared by the community. And while members of this community could establish uni-directional links to remote Patient resources under their control, they could not do the same for the remote Patient resource. In this case, a RelatedPerson resource (with two entries for patient relationships and each with the PatientRelationshipType ONESELF) would facilitate efficient and reliable record location services.

summary: "Operations" need a clearer namespacing policy to avoid clashes
details:
"operations.html" says:

> Name clashes between operations defined by different implementers can be resolved by use of the conformance statement.

But this is not an adequate approach.

To start: Operation's "identifier" is optional, and the official operations don't currently even include an identifier (e.g. there is no OperationDefinition.identifier defined for http://hl7-fhir.github.io/operation-conceptmap-translate.xml or http://hl7-fhir.github.io/operation-valueset-expand.xml). Without an identifier on the operation definitoin, a client has no chance of telling two operations apart.

But more to the point, the currnet approach to namespacing is flawed because of the interaction between "OperationDefinition.identifier" and "OperationDefinition.name": even if "identifier" is present, each operation definition still declares its own name, which determines the URL at which it is hosted. So for example, the following can occur:

1. An implementer defines and imlplements a new operation, used locally, called "$test" (with or without an identifier).

2. Later, FHIR defines an official operation called "$test" that does something different,

3. The implementer wants to support both, but can't, because they share the same name and thus would need to be hosted at the same URL.

One solution: FHIR could define  its own "official" operations ot have privileged names, e.g. by using a prefix like "fhir.", which  would yield names like "$fhir.translate" and "$fhir.populate". Then implementers would know not to define new operations whose names start with "fhir.".

I would like to suggest the following (or something to the effect of it) be added to the tags section:

--

Resource tags are considered to be an unordered set. Implementing systems SHALL not infer any meaning from the order in which tags appear. If two tags for the same resource contain the same scheme and the same term, they are considered to be duplicates. Implementing systems SHALL not infer any meaning from duplicate tags.

summary: Clarify tag list/set and tag equivalence
details:
It's not yet clear in the spec that tags are equivalent when their tag + scheme are the same. Label is irrelevant.

Since tag+scheme must be unique within the TagList and order of tags is not important, the list is actually a set.

Current wording on the http update operation indicates that the response content-location header needs to have a version, but this isn't practical if the server behind the FHIR interface isn't version aware (and has no concept of a version ID).

Relevant discussion:

[2014-09-29, 2:04:03 PM] James Agnew: in the case of one system we have a fhir interface in front of right now, there isn’t even that. it just overwrites the previous version with the new version and keeps the id the same.. doesn’t even have an update timestamp.
[2014-09-29, 2:04:25 PM] James Agnew: this sure wouldn’t be how i would design a system, but i don’t control the system, just want to put data in it
[2014-09-29, 2:07:13 PM] Paul Knapp: if they put a timestamp on it then that could server as the instance/version, but agreed when you don't control it you don't control it.
[2014-09-29, 3:25:38 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: If you have no idea when the data is changed, then you don't really have a choice other than to declare a distinct verison every time the data is queried
[2014-09-29, 3:25:57 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: So set the version id to a random guid or to the current timestamp
[2014-09-29, 4:21:45 PM] Grahame Grieve: this is problematic. Where does it say that the version id has to change?
[2014-09-29, 4:31:58 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: When the data changes?
[2014-09-29, 4:32:57 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: 1.12.0 (resources.html): "has an identified version that changes if the contents of the resource change"
[2014-09-29, 4:35:05 PM] Grahame Grieve: well, James, I think that the spec is clear: that you do have to have a version id, and it does have to change.
[2014-09-29, 4:35:19 PM] Grahame Grieve: but I'm inclined to agree with you that this is problematic
[2014-09-29, 4:35:47 PM] Grahame Grieve: Lloyd's solution - nventing a version id for every view - doesn't sit well with me either
[2014-09-29, 4:36:51 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: I agree it's a sucky solution.  It's a worst case where your sole back-end is v2 messaging that has no concept of dates or version ids or anything else that could be used to generate a version id
[2014-09-29, 4:37:57 PM] Grahame Grieve: it would be better not to do a version id at all.
[2014-09-29, 4:43:48 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: So if you can't tell if the data's changed, make it versionless?
[2014-09-29, 4:45:26 PM] Grahame Grieve: I think that this is better, yes
[2014-09-29, 4:48:44 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: I can live with that.

summary: Consistent modeling approach for body site
details:
Currently, in FHIR, body site is modeled in two ways: as a structure (Location in Condition) and as an attribute (bodySite - CodeableConcept).

CDS would like to recommend that the approach to modeling body site be consistent and we would favor the Location approach (see Condition) over the bodySite attribute as it allows for a cleaner extension approach. In CDS, we plan to add to extensions to Location - i.e., directionality and laterality beyond the anatomical location code.

We assume that in FHIR, anatomical location may precoordinate directionality and laterality. This may be common in most systems today. However, such precoordination can be problematic for more computable use cases (e.g., logic checks based on a cross-product of qualifier/location combinations, parsing of precoordinated concepts, or even cases where terminologies are not fully consistent in their precoordination). We also would like to recommend the addition of the laterality and directionality to the Location structure for those use cases where post-coordination in the model is possible.

summary: Java: Split StringType into StringType and TextType
details: In the Java implementation, please split StringType into two: StringType for values that are short in length (max: 255 or 1024) and TextType for values with a max length of 1MB. It makes no sense to store "John" in the same table that can handle 1MB of data.

In the Java implementation, please use CONSTANT_CASE: all uppercase letters, with words separated by underscores. This will also fix some of the issues of using Java reserved words such as: final

https://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/javaguide.html#s5.2.4-constant-names

Example:

public enum ObservationStatus {
    REGISTERED,
    PRELIMINARY,
    FINAL,
    AMENDED,
    CANCELLED,
    ENTERED_IN_ERROR,
    NULL;
}

details: The structures we capture to define messaging events in the spec and how they're modeled in Conformance is quite different.  As well, it's not clear why we handle defining messaging events one way and OperationDefinitions another way.  We need to get alignment between how we maintain/publish event and how it appears in Conformance (or whatever other resource we choose to use).

Value sets are under base uri: http://hl7.org/fhir/vs

 

Code systems are currently directly under http://hl7.org/fhir

It makes more sense to use a comparable base uri: http://hl7.org/fhir/cs

summary: Value set / Code system OID missing from formal definition
details:
"The OID for the value set is 2.16.840.1.113883.4.642.2.133 (OIDs are not used in FHIR, but may be used in v3, or OID based terminology systems)."

This info is not contained in the valueset anywhere, structured or unstructured (I'm basing on the Value Set resource definition and published instances thereof). While a URI may be true in environments that start with FHIR from a white page, I expect to push for OIDs wherever possible in The Netherlands because we normally already have OIDs in place and URIs impose a migration hurdle with yet another thing to maintain next to the OID amanagement they already have. Not to mention that URIs break when the domains change due to mergers etc.

In order to host the value sets in mixed environments I'm currently experiencing trouble converting them to 1 type of methodology that suits both value sets as-we-know-them-today and the-FHIR-way. I currently assign my own new OID because the info is unavailable in the resource. When the OID as assigned is exposed in the ValueSet resources all this pain goes away. Should there be value sets that have no assigned OID in other contexts, I may then and only then assign my own to register them.

summary: Clarify how complex types work with fixed values in profiles
details:
Currently, the Profile fixed value (Profile.structure.snapshot.element.definition.value[x]) has a short description that says "Fixed value: [as defined for a primitive type]", and the comments say: To specify a fixed value for a complex data type, include the child elements for the type and specify fixed values for each property independently. However the type is "*" - allows complex types, and the existing profile tooling generates complex fixed values. 

What you want depends on the context. The classic case is a codableConcept - sometimes, particularly in the spec, you want to fix, say, a particular code by system/code, but it's not important - or even useful - if other codes are provided. On the other hand, it's really relevant, particularly in implementation guides, to simply fix the value completely, and making the tooling or the author blow out all the sub children in order to fix a full value is definitely overkill. 

This proposal is to allow for fixed[x] to be complex type, and if a fixed value is specified, then that exact fixed value must be used, with no deviation. Also to add a pattern[x] : * element, with cardinality 0..1. If this is fixed, the provided element must conform to the pattern - in other words, each element / attribute / property (for JSON) must exist in the instance, but other things may also exist. This is effectively constraint by example

At present, any slicing on a list requires a discriminator. The discriminator is a field that must have a distinct value domain in each slice, and an instance processor can use the value of the discriminator to determine which slice it is dealing with without having to do speculative depth-first validation of the entire slice contents to decide which slice they are dealing with (which may be impossible, let alone feasible in computational or programmer terms)

However there are some cases where there is no possible discriminator, and there's no way to tell the content apart without full validation. And there are other cases - including a couple in CDA - where there is no single discriminator. 

This task proposes to change the cardinality of discriminator from 1..1 to 0..*. If there is one or more discriminator fields nominated, then the set of the the value domains must be unique across the defined slices. If there is no discriminator, then there is no easy to determine which slice is which (implementers are advised not to do this, but an choose to). 

(this from extensive discussion on the issue between tooling/profile developers in informal discussion in Chicago)

summary: Clarify how re-slicing works across profiles
details:
Currently, when you slice, you define a name for each new slice. The name has to be unique across the set of slices in the profile. So if profile A defines an element X with cardinality 0..*, and profile B is derived from profile A, then profile B can either:
#1 make a constraint on X with no name - in which case the profile is constraining all appearances of X; or 
#2 make a constraint on X with a name - in which case the profile is describing a specific slice on X, and the constraints only apply to that slice; or 
#3 it can do both

Then, profile C derives from profile B. Profile C can do the following:

#1 make a constraint on X with no name - in which case the profile is constraining all appearances of X; or 
#2 make a constraint on X with a different name to that used in profile B - in which case the profile is describing a specific new slice on X, and the constraints only apply to that slice; or 
​#3 make a constraint on X with the same name as that used in profile B - in which case the profile is making new constraints on the slice defined in profile B; or 
#4 - some combination of the above options

Note: it is possible for Profile C to make rules that are incompatible with profile B, in which case there is no set of instances that can be valid against profile C

What is not clear is how Profile C slices the slice defined by Profile B. This task proposes that this is achieved by a path separator - if Profile B defines the slice "example", and profile C defines the slice "example/example1", then this is deemed to be "example1" slice of the example slice. Note: we could choose any character as the separator character; we choose / since that is what openEHR uses for pretty much the same usage. 

This was discussed by the profile/tooling developers during an informal meeting at Chicago

summary: Add a property for comments to the JSON format
details:
At present, there is no explicit support for adding a comments to the JSON format. Some implementations do it informally. The comments are particularly useful in the formal examples, and one of the real problems of the JSON format is that the examples do not include comments. We should add an agreed property for putting comments in the json objects. 

This task proposes that the json property "_comments" : [ string, string] be formally documented to carry comments on the object that holds it. For primitive data types, it would go in the name_ section, along with the id and extensions. 

The specification would populate these for all the examples that have comments in the XML. This would also allow us to have examples mastered in JSON

summary: Create "best practice" guide for creating a "system URI" for Coding
details:
The Coding datatype uses a 'system' element to identify the system within which a given code is unique. When there is a need to create a custom set of codes for a particular Coding element - say using a ValueSet - it would be good to have a preferred way to define that system in a way that the recipient of a resource instance that contained an element referring to that system would be able to look it up to determine it's meaning if it was unknown.

For example it could point to a resolvable HTML page that a support person could view.

summary: search criteria shouldn't have to be tied to a structure
details: When search criteria are defined based on a resource, tying them to a structure makes good sense.  However, when search criteria are defined against extension definitions, requiring a structure is unnecessary.  The search criteria would apply wherever the extension gets used and best practice is for extensions to be defined separately from profiles.  Also, if I want to define an additional search criteria for a resource, it's not clear why I should have to create a structure to do that.  It's probably cleanest if search criteria simply point to the resource(s) they work with rather than having to define a separate structure for them to nest inside.

summary: Value set - define/concept[0..*] needs additional wording
details: Currently you may define a value set with a system, but leave out any Concepts as the relationship is 0..*. I'm told by Lloyd that may never occur on a final value set, but only in authoring a value set where a system is defined, but work is yet to be done on actual contents. I would appreciate wording along those lines on the Concept relationship to make it clear for the implementer of (normally) final value sets.

In the documentation for Messages, there is a table for various event code types. The code for query lists that it uses query as both the request and response. The response should be listed as query-response instead.
"Namespace" is a reserved word in some languages where no workaround exists.  Significant list discussion and two surveys landed on NamingSystem.  (Runner up was NamespaceSystem.)

It would be helpful to have a complete XML and JSON example of a Message on the messaging page. Implementers new to the standard will have a hard time understanding the construction of a bundle and how the various pieces fit together.

It would also be helpful to have a similar example on the MessageHeader page since that is a critical part of a FHIR message. Just having MessageHeader examples without the overall bundle context is not as helpful as it could be.

The patient compartment details are here: http://hl7-fhir.github.io/compartment-patient.html

summary: Concept Map should clarify the direction of relationships
details:
Josh Mandel: For ConceptMap.element.map.equivalence: does "narrower" mean that source is narrower than target, or vice versa? From the example data, I understand it as "source term <isNarrowerThan> target term."


[5:49:11 PM] Grahame Grieve: yes, can you make a task to clarify please


[5:49:38 PM] Josh Mandel: Also, it appears that "narrower" renders with a ">" in the web view (e.g. at http://hl7-fhir.github.io/name-use, old shows up as ">BAD", while it's "narrower" in the concept map)
[5:51:02 PM] Grahame Grieve: duh. what excellent work on my part

At present, a profile is a packaging mechanism for a set of Structural constraints, and a set of extension definitions. It was defined that why before we had any other packaging mechanisms. Structured like this, it's a pretty *big* resource (as can be seen by looking at it's definitions) and it creates some difficulties:
* it's not clear what a "profile" is - since many people refer to a structure as a profile
* it complicates the URL handling/addressing - it's not clear which structure is being addressed
* there's no real logical boundary - it's just an editing / packaging convenience, but it's also a editing / package problem too

A specific problem is that it makes FHIR not play well with other metadata registries. For instance, they could host a general data element repository where the URL for a data element (say, http://meteor.aihw.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/398625) could serve up an extension definition if the content type on the request is "application/xml+fhir". But as it stands, we either have to continue allowing ambiguity about package references, or prohibit the same URL directly 

Instead, we could break extensions and structures up - into ExtensionDefinition, and Profile. They would both have the same metadata as now, but a profile would have one structure, and an extension definition would have one extension. Most of the existing common content would be moved to a shared data type called "ElementDefinition" so they'd continue to have common content where they currently do. 

This would simplify implementation for authors, validators and users because there'd be no ambiguity about the fragment part of the URL. Nor would there be ambiguity about what a "profile" is.

We could still do packaging, but it would be done by atom or composition, and we'd get more flexibility - could include value sets, operation definitions, etc.

[7:11:08 PM] Grahame Grieve: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/extensibility.html#define

 Friday, October 17, 2014
[9:52:08 AM] Josh Mandel: Re #define: the definition of profile-definitions.html#Profile.extensionDefn.context should link to 1.12.6.0.4 . Also, in 1.12.6.0.4 the phrase "As above, separated by ';'" should be changed to "separated by ';' and optional whitespace" (because the example shows "; ").

Also, note the error in the context of the HumanName.context value for iso-21090.profile.

summary: A typo in the Page FHIR Documentation Index
details:
A typo in the Page FHIR Documentation Index：

This page provides and index to the FHIR Documentation. ...

-->

This page provides an index to the FHIR Documentation. ...

summary: A sentence needs to be corrected
details:
...which has important information about how practical use or FHIR...

-->A possible correction:

...which has important information about how to use FHIR in practice...

summary: Need to allow for Patient's where there's no indication of human vs. animal
details: While the humans involved in capturing a Patient record would likely always know whether a given patient is a human or an animal, this isn't always conveyed by underlying systems as a discrete element.  It could well be buried in text.  From a discrete information perspective, there may be no means to tell that a patient is a human or a cat - and furthermore, no need to tell.  We therefore can't use the presence or absense of "animal" to infer animal vs. human because that leaves no way to communicate "don't know/data absent".  There are lots of systems that deal with humans but may occasionally deal with an animal (e.g. community pharmacy systems) that would have no way of determining whether to send the "animal" element.  Right now, they would likely omit the element and have other systems infer that the data always referred to humans when in some cases it might not.

summary: Need to capture invariants on a per-structure basis
details: A single profile can have multiple structures based on the same resource, so Path isn't sufficient to disambiguate.  (In fact, in some cases, even within a structure, Path won't be sufficient, so look at  linking by name or path path.

Right now, List has a property "ordered: boolean", with a definition "Whether items in the list have a meaningful order."

This is really inadequate - yes, well, they have an order - good - every list is ordered - and, *the order has meaning* - well what meaning is that? 

We should change it to a codeableConcept that means that you can say what the order of the list means.

summary: Add additional language to Patient.gender comment
details:
Consider adding the following after the existing comment:

"Systems providing decision support or enforcing business rules should ideally do this on the basis of Observations dealing with the specific gender aspect of interest (anatomical, chromosonal, social, etc.)  However, because these observations are infrequently recorded, defaulting to the administrative gender is common practice.  Where such defaulting occurs, rule enforcement should allow for the variation between administrative and biological, chromosonal and other gender aspects.  For example, an alert about a hysterectomy on a male should be handled as a warning or overrideable error, not a "hard" error."

I think having explicit guidance for systems here is useful.  Just saying "it won't necessarily match" doesn't give implementers an idea of what they should do about that.

The role of OperationOutcome and the boundary between this resource and other more application-level response resources should be clarified so that implementers and designers are clear as to when OperationOutcome can be used as an application response as opposed to a transmission-level response resource, and when it is more appropriate to look to other, or a new, application response to meet a business need.

Suggestion: To serve as a light application response role OperationOutcome needs to have additional elements such as a business identifier, status etc. Severity should include success.

Also, guidance on the use or replacement of the type valueset would be useful.

Lloyd had suggested that an extension be optionally allowed to reference a resource which contains richer application-level information, for example a RESTful create of a dispense could result in an OperationOutcome. which contains errors and a reference to a Contraindication resource. Paul felt that if this is an appropriate usage then the reference would be infrastructural and therefore should not be an extension but an optional core element.

Several profiles (ex: availability.profile.json, appointment.profile.json, etc.) make references to the profile "http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/Any", which cannot be found.

Is this a real profile or just a generic (non-existing) link that represents "any" profile?
It is unclear how each of the tracker lists should be used. Please add a description of when an item should go on the "internal" tracker list, vs. the "change request" list.

summary: Do we need profiles entries for the resources in the Full Table of Contents?
details:
Do we need profiles entries for the resources in the Full Table of Contents?

For example, consider AdverseReaction, do we need 4.1.4 AdverseReaction Profiles?

    4.1 AdverseReaction
      4.1.1 AdverseReaction Examples
      4.1.2 AdverseReaction Definitions
      4.1.3 AdverseReaction Mappings
      ?4.1.4 AdverseReaction Profiles
When you click on the examples link from a Profile, you just see "To do"
E.g. On DataElement ISO 11179 profile

summary: Some extensions not rendering properly in table view
details:
The name shows up as "extension" instead of the name of the extension and there's questionmarks in the name of the profile.

As well, for complex extensions, it'd be nice if you didn't have to render the fact you were slicing - if you're dealing with extensions in an extension, slicing is a given.

The MedicationPrescription included in the document has a "contained" medication.  However, the actual medication reference within the MedicationPrescription points to an external Medication resource rather than the contained resource.

As well, Dr. Dave looks like it should be a contained resource rather than stand alone given the lack of identifying information.  Suggest fleshing out Dr. Dave so he's more appropriate as a stand-alone resource.

summary: FHIR Java Implementation: missing setter for java.util.List items
details:
Various java.util.List items in the Java implementation is missing a setter, for example: Address.line: there's a getter for line (public List<StringType> getLine) but no setter: public Address setLine(List<StringType> line):

public Address setLine(List<StringType> line) { 
      this.line = line;
      return this;
}

 

Trying to map in hibernate results in the error: "Could not find a setter for property line in class org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.Address"

summary: Some extensions in profiles are rendering oddly
details: At the specified link, look at the "enableWhen.question" extension.  The name shows up as "extension" instead of "enableWhen" and there are question marks in front of the extension type.

On the new resourcelist.html page, the resource names aren't being highlighted as hyperlinks.  The same problem exists in the tree views.

As a side-point, the hyperlinks in the footer are very hard to read.  Perhaps white with underline?

summary: A modifierExtension SHALL only modify the element which contains it and/or its children
details:
1.12.8.0.2.1 Summary: Conformance Rules for Modifier Extensions

A modifierExtension SHALL only modify the element which it contains and/or its children

-->

A modifierExtension SHALL only modify the element which contains it and/or its children

Also in the 1st DSTU version (v0.0.82).

QuestionnaireAnswers.source - The description seems to indicate that source should only be populated in the case that the person that answered the question about the patient was not the patient him/herself. The element allows for a link to a Practioner, RelatedPerson, or a Patient.

Should Patient be removed?

summary: Link to Search to Search Operation
details:
Text in Search section that reads:

Search operations are executed in one of 3 defined contexts that control which set of resources are being searched:

A specified resource type
A specified compartment, perhaps with a specified resource type in that compartment
All resources

Should include a link to search:

http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/http.html#search

(perhaps on the phrase Search operations).

summary: Hyperlinks in footer are hard to read
details: cyan on dark red is hard to read generally (and nearly impossible to read when using certain projectors).  Suggest sticking with white on red and perhaps using underline to denote hyperlinks there.

summary: The XHTML S still conform to the rules described for the Narrative
details:
1.12.7.2 Representing Resources in JSON

...

There are differences too:

...

...The XHTML S still conform to the rules described for the Narrative

---Question---

What is the meaning of "XHTML S"?  Thanks.

summary: Unclear that validate also can be used on Creates
details:
In the description here: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/http.html#validate it is mentioned above that validation is only used for updates:

"The validate interaction checks whether the attached content would be acceptable as an update to an existing resource."

However, id is optional:
 POST [base]/[type]/_validate{/[id]}

And later it is mentioned that validate can also apply on new resources:

"The content is first checked against the general specification and against the conformance profile that applies to the application. Then, if the optional [id] section is also provided, the resource is considered as a proposed update to the specific resource, and additional instance specific rules such as referential integrity and update logic (including version control) are applied as well."

I suggest the following on the first sentence:

"The validate interaction checks whether the attached content would be acceptable as a create or as an update to an existing resource."

Observation.performer: we recently added Patient as a possible performer, but the an implementer has brought up an additional use case for RelatedPerson - where the observation is made by the patient's family or other related persons. We should extend observation to support this by allowing RelatedPerson as a target for performer

summary: Add Observation.device : Reference(Device) for tracking the source of the observation
details: Use case from an equipment/eco-system manufacturer: it's necessary to record the device from which an observation originally came. Right now, we don't have this because it was envisaged that DeviceObservationReport would be used in place. But the Devices WG intends to deprecate the DeviceObservationReport resource in place of just using Observation. If that happens, then Observation.device should be added.

summary: Context conduction in contained is dangerous
details:
"Resources that are contained inline also "inherit" context from their parent resource. For instance, if the parent resource contains a "subject", and the contained resource also has a subject element defined, but does not specify any subject, a processing application may infer that the subject is the same. Note, however, that such inferences are specific to a particular circumstance. There is no rule, for instance, that the meaning of the "subject" element is the same in both parent and contained resources"

"specific to particular circumstance" is dangerous.  Particular to what circumstance?  Can a profile indicate what the context propagation rules are?  (Profiles aren't supposed to define meaning and don't have a formal way to do this.)  Having it handled by text or even implicit assumption is even worse.

There's no technical reason to allow context conduction in contained resources.  While it's true that the issue of the semantics not being available to conduct goes away, that doesn't mean there's a reason that supporting conduction is necessary and doesn't avoid all the other dangers and complexities associated with context conduction.

The specification defines the type idref that is used to reference an elemtn by it's id attibute. It's always been a bit of an oddity- overlaps with URI, but was defined to support narrative/data references mainly - the narrative/reference pages together descibe the idea of linking between the data and narrative items using id/idref

However no one has ever used this  - idref isn't allowed in the schema at either location. Only two elements are defined as idref (one in careplan and one in a fanily history profile), and these could be be defined as uri - this would be more consistent. 

Prroposal to remove idref and narrative sections about cross-linking

summary: Method to return all entries related to a patient ID
details:
Many applications have a need for the API server to return all entries related to a patient. This can be best accomplished by providing the Paitent ID.

It seems that there are a couple means (among others) to return the entire patient entry list.
1) Create a function that searches all resource types to return results from the /_search?... supported query accross the entire server. Since some resources have the patient idenifier as "patient", "subject", and "identifier", seperate queires may have to be executed andcombined.
2) Support the /_search? query acorss the entire server and ensure that all entries use a common patient identifier in the spec.

We already decided that ValueSet.name should be 0..1.  Same logic applies to ConceptMap.  It's not essential to the use of the resource.  A meaningful value that adds information beyond other information present in the resource won't necessarily exist

summary: remove the concept 'error' from .reliability code value set.
details:
Propose remove the concept 'error' from .reliability code value set.

With the introduction of the .datanotpresent element in Obs,  the code "error' in .reliability is redundant and confusing (for an  error. having .datanotpresent = "error'   and  .reliability = "error" ).  This concept is more closely aligned to .datanotpresent.

So for an error datanotpresent = "error'   and  .reliability absent.

summary: Extend Search API to support searching for contained resources
details:
At present, it's not possible to find contained resources when searching. As an example, imagine a contained value set in a questionnaire. You can search the value sets, but you can't search for this particular value set - it's ignored in the search. Mostly, actually, that's the behaviour you want. But not always. Say, you want to find all places where a particular code systems is used in the system - you also want to search contained value sets.

But right now, you can't. You can search all the questionnaires for ones that refer to value sets that use that code system, but this will include both contained and non-contained examples. And where do you have to search to find the contained value set? everything? 

This task proposes making the following changes: 
* add a search parameter "_contained" that can either be "true", "false", or "both". The default is false
* specify that when contained resources are matched, their container resources is returned 
* differentiate between matching and included resources in what is returned (depends on task to replace atom) (so that it's possible to tell whether a resoruce is included as a match or an inclusion, which presently is done solely by type)

(conclusion from a long discussion on implementers skype channel)

summary: Is the Procedure resource used for planned procedure?
details: Is Procedure Resource meant to be used for planned procedure? If yes, the descriptions on the resources are worded for procedure that have occurred.
Location of a procedure may add context for medical decision making. A newborn deliver at home may need something different that if the birth happened in a hospital.
Can the procedure resource be used for procedures that the patients perform, e.g. peritoneal dialysis, wound care, etc? If yes may need to location outside of an encounter.

summary: Need a way to specify supplies used for the procedure
details: Would supplies be a relatedItem?

summary: Specify a value set for the type of procedure
details: Diagnostic, Therapeutic, Surgical, Anaesthesia, etc?

summary: Need to specify what the procedure resulted in
details: What was the outcomes of the procedure? Were there any findings? Did something change?

summary: Need order/request classes to support notions of planned/proposed
details:
There's a need for clinical decision support and other purposes to be able to represent proposals/recommendations an planned activities such as proposal for medication, planned observation, etc.  The data captured for these is typically similar to or identical to the information captured for orders.  The only difference is that proposed and planned activities are not "authorized" (and thus may not be directly actionable).

The proposal is to leverage the existing order/request/intent resources (MedicationPrescription, DiagnosticOrder, Referral, NutritionOrder, ProcedureOrder, CarePlan, plus new ones) but allow them to convey "plans" and "proposals" for activities in addition to the actual order of an activity.

There are two options:

1. This could be done using either an immutable element on the resource to distinguish Proposal|Plan|Order (and possibly other things, e.g. "Promise").  Orders that implement plans or proposals would need to be separate instances.  Proposals and plans would be able to navigate the entire status cycle.

2. This could be done by adding "proposed" (and where appropriate, "planned") as statuses to the existing structure.  In this case, proposals could be updated to become "active" (though distinct instances would still be possible).  Once the status had changed to completed or something else, there'd no longer be a distinction about whether the original had been a "proposal" or not though.

Patient Care had expressed a preference for option #2 to allow editing a proposal and turning it into an order and not retaining the proposal as a separate distinct resource instance.

Intent  of .performer is who made the observation, not who is responsible for doing it – so organization shoul dalso be considered to be removed.  Similar to removing device as discussed in #3689.

See Screenshot for visual of proposall

summary: Two typos in the section 1.12.6.1.1 Patient Consent for Record Sharing
details:
Two typos in the section 1.12.6.1.1 Patient Consent for Record Sharing:

1) ... and/or the policy under which the patient to their registration details.

Note: No verb in the subordinate clause.

2) If they wish, they can extend the patient resource to represent the patient's participation agreeement.

Note: agreeement --> agreement

summary: Changes to Device following HL7 UDI Harmonization Pattern
details:
To allign the current resource with the outcome of the UDI Harmonization pattern:

Remove the udi string attribute as the udi string will be in the identifier or type depending on it's purpose
Add manufactureDate: dateTime 0..1 to Device
Change expiry: date 0..1 to expiry: dateTime 0..1
Define a FHIR Extension for DonorIdentificationNumber of type Identifier.
 

In V3 the type in the Device class is optional while here it is required, why and should that be relaxed for conversion purposes?  If it remains required the when a UDI string is the Identifier what should be used as the type, the DI contained within the UDI string or some other valueset?

summary: Add responsible WG to the FHIR Resource and Profile information
details: Suggest adding the responsible Work Group to Resources, Profiles (and maybe other FHIR pages) so that interested parties know who to engage for changes, usage and questions.

From very early in the design of FHIR, we've used Atom feeds as our syntax for bundling resources. We use bundles of resources for search results, transactions, messages, and documents - quite a lot, in fact. It's one of the prominent features of our API (I've sometimes referred to it as an Atom spec, not a RESTful spec). And one of the obvious ways it works - which has been controversial - is that we put resource metadata outside the resource, in the http header, or in the Atom entry wrapper.

 

In the last few weeks, several long-running threads have come together to convince the core team that this is a problem, and that if we're ever going to address it, now is the time. The primary trigger was a discussion on the FHIR implementers skype channel that followed on from our earlier email thread about re-introducing “id” into the base resource. If you care, this is visible in our skype chat logs (specifically around here -- and if you read this, scroll up, not down).

 

Anyway, the upshot of that discussion was that we were persuaded to take a serious look at changing from Atom (even though we weren't keen - it's a very large change for the core team). But as I said, it's kind of now or never (I'm trying to get all the breaking changes done at once).

 

So we’re proposing to add this kind of metadata (in JSON or XML) to every resource:

 

"meta" : {
   "id" : "23434",
   "versionId" : "12",
   "lastUpdated" : "2014-08-18T01:43:30Z",
   "ruleSet" : "http://example-consortium.org/fhir/consortium-rules",
   "profile" : ["http://example-consortium.org/fhir/Profile/patient"],
   "security" : [{
     "system" : "http://hl7.org/fhir/v3/ActCode",
     "code" : "EMP"
   }],
   "tag" : [{
     "system" : "http://example.com/codes/workflow",
     "code" : "needs-review"
   }]
 }
}

 

This includes the relevant things from Atom plus something new: ruleset (in place of the previously discussed "intrinsic profile" idea). It also clearly separates a resource's id from its current version id (which can be hard to distinguish in FHIR's Atom-based metadata).

 

We would define some new structures, so the base class model for Resources looks like:

 Resource (defines meta + language)

  +- DomainResource (defines text, extensions, contained - what we know as "resource" today)

  +- Binary (same functionality as Binary today, but defined like every other resource)

  +- Bundle (adds links + total + base + items)

  +- DeletedResource (adds resource type : used only in bundles that are history lists to mark deleted resources)

 

All of these resources will be defined the same way as all the existing resources, so that all the of the existing infrastructure just handles them naturally.

 

Here's some of our reasons why we are entertaining the idea of replacing Atom:

 

Resource-specific metadata is located differently when the resource is returned from a Search than it is when the resource is returned for a Read. A client needs to look for metadata (like id, version, update time, tags, etc.) in different places depending on which kind of operation was performed. Defining metadata as part of our resources allows a more consistent client interface, and avoids the need to re-invent wrapper syntax when using FHIR resources outside of REST (e.g. messaging or web sockets).

Many FHIR client libraries offer API calls that return Atom Entries rather than Resources -- even though we claim to ship resources around. This subtle difference trips lots of implementers over, especially when it comes to keeping track of metadata like resource ids and versions.

Defining our own Bundle structure lets us re-use FHIR's existing algorithm for handling the conversion between XML and JSON (and this can extend to emerging formats like RDF, when we get there).

Atom’s design (and XML schema in particular) is more complicated to implement than one we'd design.  For example, Atom allows metadata to be specified in any order, whereas in FHIR XML, all other properties are generally ordered.  This would simplify code-generation from Atom schemas. - and we’ve had other implementers struggle with code generation from the Atom schemas.  (We’re not advocating schema-based code generation - there are better ways such as using the reference implementations.  However, we’d like to support that approach where implementers really want to do it.)

Using Atom complicates FHIR's mime types: in FHIR XML, we currently have 2 mime types: application/xml+fhir and application/Atom+xml

Atom requires identifiers to be absolute urls and this is more complicated than simple identifiers, where we can use identifiers more naturally (absolute where appropriate, or just identifiers where appropriate).

The metadata would have to be  duplicated outside the resource even if we chose to move it into the resource

A new Bundle format will let us directly express the things we care about, rather than jumping through Atom-specific hoops -- for example to express the total number of search results or document deleted records.

We can do tags more naturally rather than shoehorning the structures into url pairs in Atom category elements (which are a bit of a problem because these are not used consistently elsewhere anyway)

Atom requires a “title”, “author” and “published date” for every entry, even though FHIR attaches no meaning to this field.

Our use of Atom effectively duplicates narrative (in entry.summary and content.[resource].text).

We could make binary resources work more naturally.  While it wouldn’t have narrative, it could still be described/defined in the same manner as other resources, with the base64 content contained in a single resource element.(this would make it fit into the reference implementations without being a ‘special case’)

We've never figured out how to implement the /document end point because documents aren't resources. (For example: the /document endpoint is theoretically supposed to return "a bundle of bundles". But we've never made this work in our implementations, because an Atom-based Bundle is not, itself, a FHIR resource.). Defining our own Bundle structure would allow FHIR Documents to be first-class resources.

Atom imposes obligations on the identifiers. For example, "id" is a required property. (This is a future issue for flexible query that I've already struggled with, though this issue is over the horizon for most.)

Atom turns into a problem if we want to talk about extrinsic vs intrinsic tags (that’s an earlier discussion we had about tags that are inherently linked to the content, and others that are ephemeral. Security has some identified use cases where a security tag can’t be removed without explicitly changing the resource, though their analysis is not yet complete).

There’s some peculiarities in the way CDA identifiers map to FHIR because a document maps to Atom, and so we’re forced to map into Atom - and, in fact, there are still some todos here.

We've never tried to apply profiles to Atom, but there's reasons to think that we'd need to (value sets for security labels, for instance).

One of the expected benefits of using Atom was that we could use off-the-shelf libraries that supports Atom.  However, in practice our use of deleted resources, extra links for number of matching records, etc. has meant that off-the-shelf Atom libraries have not been broadly helpful for working with FHIR bundles. (For example, most FHIR client libraries ship with a from-scratch Atom implementation.)

 

There's been both ballot responses and tasks requesting change in this regard. Here's a current task: http://gforge.hl7.org/gf/project/fhir/tracker/?action=TrackerItemEdit&tracker_item_id=2889&start=0

 

To help illustrate what these proposals mean:

The new developers' introduction at http://hl7-fhir.github.io/overview-dev.html describes "meta" and how it works (note: this is out of sync completely with the rest of the spec, and has some broken links)

Definitions for Bundle are at http://hl7-fhir.github.io/NewBundle.html, and Binary here: http://hl7-fhir.github.io/binary.html (note that generator build tool doesn't know about all this yet, so binary is shown with the wrong parent there, and "NewBundle" is a temporary name. This is as far as I can get without changing the tool for the class structure above)


 

Some notes about all this:

There's nearly zero functional impact here - this is almost purely about the wire syntax, and the way the API represents things.

Existing Resource designs are unaffected, except in one regard:

Since bundles are now resources, a Reference(Any) could now potentially reference a document rather than a specific resource. We've identified this technical possibility, but not performed any serious analysis of whether this would be a good or a bad idea.

Unless you work with the API directly (as opposed to just being concerned with the contents of the resources), you don't need to worry about the impact of this change other than the "reference to a document" question

This is (pretty obviously) a big breaking change to the API. For my server, I maintain a single server source with conditional compiles for DSTU1 and the current version, and I don't know whether I'll be able to make that work after this change.

The size of this change has been a factor - we've said we'll make changes where they're justified, but this is a BIG one. So the benefits have to be big. I've become persuaded that this is worth doing (we've made many other breaking changes, so the mere fact it's a breaking change isn't a problem per se, but the size of this is a factor) for the following reasons:

It makes life simpler for implementers

It's more capable of solving future problems (we need to invest a lot of work in query flexibility, and I kept tripping over Atom restrictions in planning this)

It's easier to document

It aligns better with other specifications (e.g. SCIM, oData, other RESTful APIs)

We're making this in response to implementer experience in the real world


 

Open Issues

There's still a few things that this proposal doesn't solve:

This proposed redesign doesn't settle the question of intrinsic vs extrinsic security labels (still an open issue)

It may be that we define specific subclasses of bundle for specific uses - the 5 uses we know of have different rules - but they are also highly overlapping, so we haven't yet made a decision on that (but you still have to be able to tell them apart, whatever we do)

summary: Conformance behavior for operations is unclear
details: While some operation parameters are optional, it is not clear whether it is acceptable for a server to ignore those parameters (or for that matter, to ignore required parameters), nor whether it's necessary to communicate in some fashion that parameters have been ignored.  This is particularly important when looking at forward compatibility when new optional parameters might be introduced that won't be supported by older servers.

summary: Request to separate Birth Date from Birth Time
details:
Using the FHIR DateTime data type for birth date and birth time adds in complexity of time zone handling as there's an expectation that if there are hours/minutes specified, a Time Zone should also be included.

While most systems have a birth date for a patient, most systems do not have a birth time for a patient or don't have a strong use case for producing/consuming birth information with time zone considerations included.

Unlike other timestamps, a person's birth date/time is something that would not typically be qualified with time zone information. For example, if a person is born at 11:00 PM in New York City on 11/30/1953, no system is going to record/capture this as 0400 12/1/1953 UTC.

Also, the patient in question will always refer to his/her birth date as 11/30.

I would propose one of the two paths forward:

1. change birthDate to have a data type of "date". Then, implementers with a need for birthTime could add this in via an extension to include birthTime

2. change birthDate to have a data type of "date" and incldue birthTime as part of the standard.

Personal preference would be #1 but would like to discuss with PA group. We should also discuss deathDate to see if has similar considerations.

summary: FHIR Test Server and search by _profile parameter support
details:
The public test server has the "_profile" search parameter in the Patient resource in the conformance metadata so it claims it is supported, but it is not implemented.

Created a test patient that explicitly conforms to a profile has same results regardless of
whether the _profile parameter is in search parameter or not.

Assume it would return only the resources that are explicitly tagged by that profile URI as described in spec.

Reference: section 2.2.6 "Selecting resources by tag, profile or security label"

First tried using profile=http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/us-core.profile.xml

These all return the same results even the one with a bogus profile URL.

Test searches:

http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient/_search?_profile=http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/us-core.profile.xml&_count=10&active=true&birthdate=1973-05-31


http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient/_search?_profile=bogus.profile.xml&_count=10&active=true&birthdate=1973-05-31

http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/Patient/_search?_count=10&active=true&birthdate=1973-05-31

Dynamically created a patient record as such then deleting it after running some tests to confirm.

_count isn't being respected in the above query.
=< and => are supported

Propose adding the Person resource as defined below. Primary use case is to support patient identity mangement and qualified record linking across patient identity domains.

<Person xmlns="http://hl7.org/fhir">
<!-- from Resource: extension, modifierExtension, language, text, and contained -->
<identifier><!-- 0..* Identifier An identifier for the person as this Person § --></identifier>
<name><!-- 0..* HumanName A name associated with the Person § --></name>
<telecom><!-- 0..* ContactPoint A contact detail for the individual § --></telecom>
<gender value="[code]"/><!-- 0..1 male | female | other | unknown § -->
<birthDate value="[dateTime]"/><!-- 0..1 The date and time of birth for the individual § -->
<address><!-- 0..* Address Addresses for the individual § --></address>
<photo><!-- 0..* Attachment Image of the person --></photo>
<patientLink> <!-- 0..* Link to a Patient resource that concerns the same actual person § -->
 <patient><!-- 1..1 Reference(Patient) The Patient resource that the link refers to § --></patient>
 <assurance value="[code]"/><!-- 1..1 Level1 | Level2 | Level3 | Level4 - based on NIST Authentication Levels qualifying evidence supporting link § -->
</patientLink>
<active value="[boolean]"/><!-- 0..1 Whether this Person's record is in active use § -->
</Person>

It's common to keep a scanned copy of a paper request form, and link this to the order (in diagnostic systems). We could make this supportable with little impact by allowing DiagnosticOrder.supportingInformation to refer to a DocumentReferemce

summary: The list of FHIR datatypes should be explicit about "element" and derived types
details:
The list of FHIR datatypes (in this case I mean the list as specified in the valueset at http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/data-types.html and http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/defined-types.html (which also includes the resources)) can easily be (mis?)understood to also be relevant for use in Profile.extensionDefn.context.

However, in extensionDefn.context, the value "Element" is also valid, indicating that the extension is also valid on any complex type (including resources and nested structures). This means we should either document this at the description of extensionDefn.context or we should add "Element" to this valueset.

Conversely, these valuesets contain constrained types (like Money and Distance), which are however not to be used in the element Profile.structure.type. 

These valuesets are used in the following contexts:

* data-types: Profile.structure.element.definition.type.code (so, adding Element would again result in incorrect use of Element in this context)

* defined-types: Profile.structure.type (removing the derived types from this list would not have side-effects)

To resolve this issue we need to decide on two things:

* where are the type names in Extension.context taken from?
* why are derived types not allowed in Profile.structure.type? Are they considered secondary citizens in the type system?

and maybe:

* Can Extension.context not simply be taken from the defined-types list, and why is do we distinguish between a "Resource" and "datatype" context for extensions?

details:
Following two rules should be identical but value is referenced as an element and as an attribute:

1. <xpath value="not(f:conformance/@value='example' and f:isExtensible/@value='false')"/>
2.  <xpath value="not(f:conformance/value='example' and f:isExtensible.value='false')"/>
 
The second form should be changed to the first form.

summary: New desciption in the spreadsheet Search tab name column incorrectly states to use camel case
details: The description text on the name field of teh Serach tabin the new spreadsheets incorrectly states to use lower-camel case when lower case is required.

summary: consider enhancing Patient.Communication to have "needs interpreter" in standard
details:
It appears that for simplicity's sake, the languages that a patient understands has been implemented as a CodeableConcept (list). Where a patient is a native speaker, the specification sets the expectation that there is Patient.communication ought to be kept empty. This will likely be a large percentage of exchanges of the patient resource.

When Patient.communication is provided, however, I believe that  a user of a client application that is querying a FHIR server may not be able to use the Patient.communication data in a meaningful way because of the absence of information regarding the patient's proficiency level with speaking the native language.

We should consider enhancing Patient.Communication to track proficiency level and/or "needs interpreter" information as I believe that the majority of the systems that would track a patient's languages would also track this information.

Places where patients language is tracked along-side other "modifier" about that language:

HL7v2 LAN segment: LAN-2 = language, LAN-3 = Ability Code, LAN-4 = Proficiency Code

UK national EMPI service -> "Language Communication" object contains the language along with "Interpreter required indicator".

I don't know of systems that track whether or not the patient can read vs. write the language that is being recorded. I do know of systems that explicitly track "needs interpreter". I'm thinking that the later might be something worth including as part of Patient.communication (and thus it would need to be expanded from being just a CodeableConcept).

Submitting for discussion at the next available PA group meeting.

summary: Create operation - should the effects of idempotence be described?
details: The create operation is different to other operations, in that it's distinctively not idempotent, and repeating it is not necessarily a good idea - not that you can not repeat it if you get no response. This is probably worth discussing on the create operation

summary: Query parameter as type extension is confusing
details:
Query parameter as type extension is convenient (it fits) but it's like comparing a door to a cork screw because it opens. It will likely cause confusion for new implementers till the end of days.
Suggested alternatives.
- A new type name-value-pair
- A complex nested type
- Parameter as its own type (allows for modeling of modifier and other-than-equal comparisons)

Advice is needed for how to create a Provenance.signature and how to validate one so that the signature survives various movements. Or do we just indicate that signatures are not intended to survive movements?

Specifically troubling:

* How are signatures to be handled by a receiving system that imports the resource for use? That is it encorporates the resource content, and likely fixes up the References to local copies of the resource?

** Should a counter-signature be used? That is the importing system will validate the incoming signature, and then counter sign the fixedup resource, which should be a new version with a new Provenance.

* How to handle when References are included in the resource being signed?

** Do they get turned into relative URLs?

*** If a system imports the resource and 'fixes up' the References to point at local copies of the referenced resource, then the signatures will fail to validate

** Do they get turned into just the unique part, without the URL root?

** Do they get turned into _id?

** Do they get nulled?

** How are versioned Referenced resources identified?

** Do you seralize the Referenced resource along with the resource? If so how deep?

* How to handle metadata?

** Which metadata is included in the signature? Which is not?

* How are signatures to be handled when the resource server gets re-located, changing the URL root?

summary: Some examples, e.g. for MedicationDispense, use a dateTime without timezone
details:
Some example files, e.g. MedicationDispense ("dispense.whenPrepared" and "dispense.whenHandedOver"), use a dateTime with hours:mins:seconds but do not specify a timezone. However the dateTime spec states that "If hours and minutes are specified, a time zone SHALL be populated".

The SHALL should probably be honored and the examples should all be provided with timezones.

summary: Change allowable values for logical id for a resource and a version
details:
Presently, a resource logical id is allowed to be 1-36 characters, a..z, '-', and '.'. The intent is to allow a variety of id schemes including OID and UUID. A key point is that the id is limited in length, since this must be indexed, and matching is always exact. 

There's a couple of issues with this:
- 36 chars is not long enough for some OIDs, and some complex id generation schemes (sometimes required for composite identifiers where systems are mapping concepts into FHIR)
- we say somewhere that A..Z is allowed, but don't allow this
 

Also, the change to the bundle/resource format has resulted in additional validation and many existing identiifers in the spec weren't valid. For now, I have adjusted the publication tooling to use the regex ''[A-Za-z0-9\-\.]{1,64}'. We should determine what it should be, and fix up resource identities to conform to it.
The examples for DocumentReference do not meet QA requirements.
The examples are not complete enough.

summary: ImagingStudy doesn't have good enough examples
details:
The ImagingStudy doesn't have good enough examples.

summary: SecurityEvent could be renamed as it is useful beyond security use-cases
details:
The EHR workgroup has mapped medical-records lifecycle change logs and found that SecurityEvent fills the need. This effort was not looking for any additional information in SecurityEvent, nor do they want to extend SecurityEvent to record 'what was changed'. Thus it is potentially reasonable to rename SecurityEvent to something that makes it more clear that it is a method of logging that an event has happened.

Note it is already known that SecurityEvent is useful for Privacy use-cases.

The current FamilyHistory genetics-pedigree model does not make it explicitly clear the gender of extended relatives.  While to RoleCodes for immediate relatives are implied (e.g.  PAUNT = paternal aunt, and SIS = sister are assumed to be a female relatives), with extended relatives the use of codes falls apart ( "MCOUSN" = maternal cousin, it is not clear if this is a male or female... what about 1st cousin once removed - female ... 2x removed? ).  Including gender in the model ( FamilyHistory.relation.gender = M/F or Unk ) make this explicit.  The relationship for extended relatives ('EXT' or cousins ) can be calculated by tranversing the directed acylic graph, which is necessary when drawing the pedigree at the minor trade-off of adding complexity/redundancy to the model.

In support of CQI working group at a minimum there needs to be stricter invariant constraints added to immunization resource based on whether refusedIndicator value is true or false.

There are no rules to catch invalid immunization cases (e.g. refusedIndicator=false with explanation.refusalReason present).

Definitions:

* Immunization.refusedIndicator (1..1): indicates if the vaccination was refused (aka not administered).
* Immunization.explanation.reason (0..*): codes for "Reasons why a vaccine was administered".
* Immunization.explanation.refusalReason (0..*): The reason why a vaccine administration was refused (Refusal or exemption reasons, binding NoImmunizationReason)
* Immunization.reaction (0..*): Categorical data indicating that an adverse event is associated in time to an immunization.

 

invariant-1:

if immunization was administered (refusedIndicator=false) then explanation.refusalReason SHALL be absent.

xpath: not(f:refusedIndicator/@value='false' and exists(f:explanation/f:refusalReason))

invariant-2:

if immunization was not administered (refusedIndicator=true) then there SHALL be no reaction nor explanation.reason present.

xpath: not(f:refusedIndicator/@value='true' and (count(f:reaction) > 0 or exists(f:explanation/reason)))

Added schematron rules:

    <sch:rule context="/f:Immunization">
      <sch:assert test="not(f:refusedIndicator/@value='false' and exists(f:explanation/f:refusalReason))">inv-1: if immunization was administered then explanation.refusalReason SHALL be absent.</sch:assert>
      <sch:assert test="not(f:refusedIndicator/@value='true' and (count(f:reaction) > 0 or exists(f:explanation/reason)))">inv-2:if immunization was not administered then there SHALL be no reaction nor explanation.reason present.</sch:assert>
    </sch:rule>

MedicationStatement has a "wasNotGiven" flag. When the flag is true, there must be a time or time period when the medication wasn't given. Using the "whenGiven" element to express the time period the medication was not given is an oxymoron. Either we can add a "whenNotGiven" element, or change the name of whenGiven to something that would apply whether the medication was given or not, such as "effectiveTime". I would prefer the latter.

summary: Clarify when OperationOutcome rather than another resource is appropriate
details: A resource proponant in their Resource Proposal raised the question as to when an OperationOutcome as apposed to another more application oriented Resource, such as Contraindication, would be most appropriate as the Response. In particular this issue discussed in FMG related to clarification of hte role of OperationOutcome as a transport-level or application-level content model.

summary: Clarification of how to implement search on boolean fields (e.g. Patient.active)
details:
For a Patient resource, in Search Parameters, 'active' is type 'token' and in the Resource Content, 'active' is type 'boolean'. However, the search spec allows token search for 'Coding, a CodeableConcept or an Identifier type, and also from a code', which implies that we shouldn't search for a boolean value using a token parameter.

The intent appears sensible (../Patient?active=true etc.), but it is not explicit how this should be implemented.

Possible solutions:

1. Clarification of the token search parameter type to include this case

2. Introduction of a boolean search parameter type

summary: Immunization not given is not always a refusal; also missing invariants
details:
The value set no-immunization-reason contains various reasons for not giving an immunization, including but not limited to refusal. The name of the element, refusalReason, is therefore misleading, since the reasons are broader: e.g., the patient might be immune due to prior exposure, or the vaccine was simply out of stock. I suggest two changes: (1) change "refusedIndicator" to "notGivenIndicator" and (2) change "refusalReason" to "notGivenReason".  If this isn't acceptable, then the value set for refusal reason should include only refusal reasons, not other types of exemptions.

A related issue is that there are no invariants that prevent (e.g.) having a refusal reason when the vaccine wasn't refused, or documenting an adverse reaction when the vaccine was not administered.

summary: add 'other' as an option for encounter.class
details: encounter.class is a required, fixed-value field. Adding 'other' to the possible values will support systems that don't have a value that matches one of the current set.

summary: resource reference search bug -- should allow search on resource type as well
details:
Per emails with Grahame Grieve, who confirmed the issue, a search for                 http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/DiagnosticReport?subject._id=Patient%2F3

should return the results that

http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/DiagnosticReport?subject._id=3

does.

Full email is copied below.

---- email ----

From: grahameg@gmail.com [mailto:grahameg@gmail.com] On Behalf Of Grahame Grieve
Sent: Thursday, November 06, 2014 1:33 AM
To: Ting, Jeffrey
Subject: Re: resource reference search

 

it should work - can you create at ask on the HL7 gForge system for me to fix it (use "FHIR Test Servers")

thanks

Grahame

 

 

On Tue, Oct 21, 2014 at 12:30 AM, Ting, Jeffrey <jeffrey.ting@systemsmadesimple.com> wrote:

Hi Grahame,

 

Why can’t

                http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/DiagnosticReport?subject._id=Patient%2F3

return the results that

                http://fhir.healthintersections.com.au/open/DiagnosticReport?subject._id=3

does?

 

To ask in other words, how do I search for resource references using the full “<resource type>/<resource ID>”?

 

Thank you,

-Jeff

summary: reference ISO 18232 in the definition of the id data type
details: ISO 18232 is a forth coming specification that specifies the same content as the id data type, though the id data type is not quite so constrained. The definition of the id data type should reference ISO 18232, and mention the differences
