details: Clarify the relationship between quantity and rate and what happens if rate is not continuous.

summary: Update example f201 to use dose, timing, and medication (remove the todos)

details: Implement the changes that are require to align the Immunization and MedicationAdministration resources.

summary: Clarify the relationship of Medication.package and Medication.product
details: Add a clarifying example to the resource description showing the nature of Product and Packaging and the relationship between them.

summary: Clarify the scope of MedicationAdministration as it is currently unclear.
details:
The current scope of the Medication Adminstration resource is unclear.  Change it to be the following:

Describes the event of a patient consuming or otherwise being administered a medication.

summary: What is the purpose of allowing multiple dosage instructions?
details: Add a rationale for when multiple Dosage Instruction elements would be used.  As well, ensure that we have examples that show the use of multiple elements.

It is common to want to capture whether a medication is "active" or not even if you don't know what the date is.  (It may make sense to have an invariant that you can't be "active" if there's an end date, but perhaps you can have an active med that has an end date.)

summary: Consent shouldn't be a sub-type of Contract
details: Resources need to reflect how data is used in real systems.  I'm not aware of any systems that would reasonably mix patient directives information with insurance policies or other contracts.  The commonality of data elements or logical modeling is not a primary consideration in whether distinct resources should be used.  No implementer would reasonably be expected to look under Contract for patient directives and many of the data elements are totally inappropriate.

summary: Consent Directive does not appear to be aligned with the 80%
details: The elements in Consent need to reflect what most systems through-out the world currently capture around consent directives and this resource contains numerous elements that are certainly not used by 80% of systems in the world that provide consent for information sharing.  If you want to create a more complex profile reflecting some particular US initiative which has more sophisticated requirements, that's fine.  However, the base structure must be defined to reflect the 80%.

summary: Questionnaire - why is limited to medications and immnizations in the example.
details: If these are examples only the wording should be clear.

summary: Questionnaire - why is limited to medications and immnizations in the example.
details: If these are examples only the wording should be clear.

summary: Add "Barriers to Care" as alias for Alert

details: Per Connectathon 8 conversation with Grahame Patient search criteria should be enhanced to allow for two parameters regarding deceased status: true/false or a date.

summary: Should schema for patient deceased status break first normal form (1NF)?
details:
Summary: Currently the patient deceased field breaks from first normal form (1NF). One proposal out of Connectathon8 is to create a new construct allowing for nullable boolWithDetails which would allow for true/false patient is deceased, and an optional deceasedDate field only allowed if deceased is true. This is in lieu of having the deceased field's datatype be determined at run-time.

Details:

The Patient.Deceased Skype conversation opened up a bit of a wormhole on Saturday 1/17/15. There is an understood complexity underlying true/false a patient is deceased, and if they are deceased and the deceased date is known what was that date? In addition, at the heart of the FHIR model is a desire to prevent individuals from sending a data conflict – eg. deceasedBool: F, deceasedDate: 1/17/15.

The current FHIR model attempts to resolve this by accepting either true, false, or a date. If a date is populated, it is known the patient is deceased and passed on that date. If true is sent then it is understood the patient is deceased but the deceased date is unknown. Lastly, if false the patient is not deceased.

In testing the Epic FHIR endpoint returns

<deceasedBoolean>false</deceasedBoolean>

<deceasedDate>0001-01-01T00:00:00</deceasedDateTime>

Which corresponds with deceased: False and C# implementation of DateTime.Min, often used to represent the a known null but for cast as a DateTime. This, however, according to Grahame and the FHIR model is an invalid value and will throw an exception in Ewouk’s FHIR library for .NET since the Deceased field is first cast as a FhirBoolean and then attempts to be cast as FhirDateTime, which is invalid.

 

The FHIR implementation is not of first normal form, meaning you don’t know what type you’re getting back. Thus, writing code against this is hard. The problem itself, as Grahame points out, is hard and which it seems everyone agrees with. At the end of the day it boils down to how much logic should be put in the model vs left to the implementation of the model.

Conversation can be found here between 2015-01-17 19:22:42Z and 2015-01-17 20:16:29Z.

summary: Should Given and Family name fields of HumanName be strings, not IEnumerable<string>?
details:
Proposal: As a matter of consistency in interpretation by receiving systems and consistency in format by sending systems, Given and Family name elements of HumanName class be strings instead of IEnumerables. 

Details:

I’m trying to best understand how one should go about working with the Patient.Name element. I can see that a Patient.Name is defined as a list of HumanNames, which are each comprised of FamilyName, GivenName, Use, Text (Full name) as well as a number of other elements. At first glance I’d expect that if you wanted to get the patient’s name you would loop over the list of Patient.Names selecting the HumanName with the highest ranked Use per your application’s needs.

Where things get tricky regarding interpretation of a patient’s name is once you’ve narrowed down to a single HumanName you wish to use, both FamilyName and GivenName are IEnumerables with no relationship between the two; this results in a Cartesian production, for which I don’t think the receiving system has sufficient information to make that interpretation.

Let’s say a source system sends out the following HumanName:

{

  given:["Kathleen", "Kathy", "Kay"],

  family:["Smith", "Jones"],

  use: “Official”

}

 

For this patient, there are several possible displayable names you could list out:

  Kathleen Smith

  Kathleen Jones

  Kathy Smith

  Kathy Jones

  Kay Smith

  Kay Jones

It's possible that this person never went by the names Kathleen Smith or Kathleen Jones.  The name "Kathleen" is on her birth certificate, but she never uses it.  To add additional complexity, when she was married, she decided to go by "Kay" (which is what her new husband affectionately calls her) instead of "Kathy".  In this case, there should be only 2 legitimate names for this patient:

  Kathy Smith

  Kay Jones

 

While that’s not necessarily the most helpful way to send out a patient name it is a perfectly valid one. Additionally, if the expectation is that the different name variations are placed into different HumanName objects then why are FamilyName and GivenNames IEnumerables instead of just a string element each? For a scenario where someone has multiple nicknames I would expect that they send out multiple HumanNames each with the Use: Nickname. By making GivenName and FamilyName strings instead of IEnumerable<string> there is an association between the family and given names of a patient at different points in time the source system is aware of. Furthermore, it precludes sending systems from having semantically different and yet acceptable sending formats and precludes receiving systems from interpretation errors.

 

Revisiting the first scenario, with Family and Given names as IEnumerables I think I’ve shown that are myriad ways sending systems could send the values and a myriad ways for receiving systems to interpret each. With Family and Given Names as only strings, for each Given & Family name combination there is no longer flexibility in what name a patient may go by at any particular point in time and how it is to be sent by the sending system or interpreted by the receiving system.

 

And, for the purposes of convenience, if a patient has only a single family name and given name, having those two fields as IEnumerables means parsing those two fields into the patient’s name is a more significant exercise than if they were simply just strings each. I realize there are Text and TextElement elements which are the full representation of that patient’s name, but given that they are not required fields and do not delineate what is family, given, suffix, prefix, etc. they cannot be relied upon as anything but an optional convenience.

summary: Need a short description and link to the ValueSet Profile(s) on the ValueSet resource page
details: It is important to be able to easily travers to the main profile for value sets from the resource page. Also a paragraph that describes how the profile utilizes the resource to make a more useful resource.

summary: Include common resource elements in resource profile definitions
details: The 1.12.0.1 section describes that all resources have a common set of elements/attributes, but those common elements/attributes are defined in the base profiles for resources. I believe that all elements of a resource type should be included in the base profile.

summary: Make DocumentManifest work for supporting documentation for claims
details:
Currently DocumentManifest *almost* can handle the use cases driving the design of http://hl7-fhir.github.io/supportingdocumentation.html -- but it doesn't quite fit. 

* Add "Attachment" to the allowed types of "content"

* Add "Organization" to the allowed types of "author"

* Decrease minimum cardinality on masterIdentifier --> 0

(The latter change is needed because the documents being sent in response to a request for supporting documentation may not really have a "master identifier" -- it might just be a collection of documents brought together ad-hoc for this particular purpose.)

Observation.valueQuantity takes a value for an observation with a specified unit of measurement. The unit of measurement system is referred to by: Observation.valueQuantity.system and Observation.valueQuantity.code. It doesn't refer to the version of the unit of measurement system that is being used.

summary: Clarify the relationship of DeviceComponent to Device
details:
This item is related to #3914 .

The DeviceComponent allows to change the configuration of the device without having to change the device resource instance. The lifecycle of the configuration may be completely dfifferent than the one of the device itself.

Hence, this explanation should be added to the section 5.9.2 (Boundaries and Relationships) in the resource description.

summary: Reuse HTTP status code semantics in the transaction result
details:
There's a set of request/response semantics that we capture with http status codes on the restful api, and currently there's a different set of semantics associated with the status/resource meta/deleted (backbone element) and it is not clear how they map to each other.

We see value in the semantics we currently have on the RESTful API, and want to be able to reuse it in the transaction bundle.

Suggestion (see attachments).

We realize this requires a reengineering of the current Bundle/BundleEntry/Deleted structure in Bundle, but we also feel that the current interplay between BundleEntry.status/Resource.meta/Deleted is too implicitly modelled and perhaps modelling these as explicit element groups under BundleEntry would be preferable.

Present: 

* Josh Mandel
* Ewout Kramer
* Steven Fine (Cerner)
* Kevin Shekleton (Cerner)
* Preshant Trivedi (HSIC)

The spreadsheet of equivalent statuses have a lot of "equivalent" statuses that aren't in fact equivalent.  For example, "entered in error" is *not* the same as "noshow".  And "active" for Profile and "active" for NutritionOrder don't really mean the same thing either.  It's not clear how this spreadsheet is actually used, but if we want it to be meaningful, it needs to be cleaned up.

summary: Add best practice narrative on suppressing data for client access of a resource
details:
Is it allowable to return only a subset of the data?  

What if this is a read-only situation (less risk of receiving incomplete updates)

Should we use dataAbsentReason on elements left out

Should we tag the instance to indicate that it misses data?

summary: Explain what "Aliases" means when defining fields in *-definitions.html (and perhaps rename it to " Called")
details:
The "-descriptions" of a Resource's fields somtimes includes a set of "Aliases" (see, for example, content at http://hl7-fhir.github.io/imagingstudy-definitions.html#ImagingStudy.series). It's unclear, howerver, what "Aliases" means. For example:

 * Are Aliases equivalent to this field?

 * Are Aliases merely "similar to" this field?

 * How do Aliases relate to mappings?

 

It would be good to add a "help" or "?" link next to Aliases to explain the meaning of this term.  And perhaps it might be better to rename "Aliases" to something more like "Related Terms".

(For an example of the confusion that this can cause, see #5286)

summary: Base resource discusses narrative under scope and usage but this is captured in domainResource
details:
Base resource discusses narrative under scope and usage but this is captured in domainResource.   "contains a human-readable XHTML representation of the content of the resource"

 So this bullet should be removed or discussed in the paragraph:

"Most resources are derived from Domain Resources - they also contain text, contained resources, extensions, and data elements specific to the particular domain of the resource. There is a special type of resource called Bundle for groups/lists of resources."

Splitting Base REsource from DomainResource is frankly confusing.  I can never find the domanResource since I always look at the base resource.  I'm sure there is a good reason but I when reading the spec I think it would prefer all the elements in one Base resource since you need to look at both places

Fix definition of .birthDate - for both Practitioner and Patient change from :"The date and time of birth for the individual"  to "The date of birth for the individual"

Also suggest creating  a standard extension .birthTime element for Patient resource as well adding guidance in the comments for .birthDate to use this extension to express the birthTime.
The intro paragraph refers to "the document resource" but should say "the DocumentReference resource".

The last paragraph of the "Scope/Usage" section states " The conditions represented in this resources are sometimes described as "Problems", and kept as part of a problem list." However, this is in conflict with the status and timing attributes listed in the resource, which seem to indicate a use more similar to an observation.  Thus, it is not clear if this represents the "Condition" as represented at a point in time (e.g. a condition as present as an assement/impression section of a note), as opposed to something followed followed over time (e.g. remains on a problem list)and representing something observed on several occations.  For example, if encounter 0..1, and severity 0..1, and dateAsserted 0..1 then this implies that a patient might be seen for a condition (e.g. a condition recorded in a note for that visit), and the identifier for the condition would be required to be _different_ if the patient was seen at another encounter for follow up of that same condition, where a different severity (eg. resolved, worse, stable) was noted.   

The instance identifier of the concept on the problem list would NOT change identifiers between visits, would most commonly be evaluated on several encounters, and may even change names or codes as the understanding of the clinical process is understood more completely.   The status on a problem list might represents the current last known observed state, but often does not if the problem has not been observed recently, and a statement that a patients condition has resolved DOES NOT imply that they never were observed to have the condition.  Using the current FHIR model, if condition means only the item on the problem list as the last know state, then there is no way to determine when/if the problem was active because the last dateAsserted would represent the time the condition was cleared.

To fix I propose a separate resource for the item on the problem list which is called 'Concern' to align with prior patient care modeling (e.g. the 'concern' as recorded on a 'problem list' initally recorded as "Rash" and perhaps later recorded as 'Psoriasis') and leave this 'condition' resource to mean the point to record point in time observations (e.g a problem list as it exists in a note, thus encounter 0..1, dateAsserted 0..1, etc) and add clarification that the 'concern' resource representing items on lists which purposed for are followed a condition over a period of time, representing a set of condition /observations,  (e.g. items typically found on 'Problem lists' in an EMR).

summary: XML tools zip is broken in the development branch
details:
The downloads page (http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/downloads.html#refimpl) has a link to XML Tools. While that link is traversable, the zip file is corrupt. 

Also, I would be interested in knowing if the rendering stylesheet in that zip, once fixed, has been updated to use the Bundle resources for documents.

summary: Expansion and compose should allow for caseSensitive or define should loose the attribute
details:
If caseSensitive is in the 80% for define, it shall be in the 80% for an expansion/compose. I'd love to kill caseSensitive on define, but if it is really deemed important, it should be consistently represented on expansion and compose.

For compose one could reason that it should be a know meta item for the given codesystem but I don't think one should count on all valueset readers/implementers to have that knowledge hence again: if it really important enough to carry in ValueSet at all it should be consistently done.

In the DECOR format for ValueSets we keep multiple languages for the description of the value set and concepts sort of like the Designation in the FHIR ValueSet. But ValueSet.name and ValueSet.description do not support multiple languages

In converting the one to the other I would need to choose what language I intend to have and convey that language on ValueSet.language.

ValueSets are likely to serve multiple audiences in multiple languages. Shouldn't that be catered for? I mainly feel that datatype String is missing a language attribute:
<element>
    <language value="x"/>
    <string value="x"/>
</element>

Which would make a lot more resources benefit.

ImagingStudy.url Change "WADO-RS URI where Study is available." to "WADO-RS resource where the Study is available."

ImagingStudy.series.numberOfInstances Change "Sequence that contains attributes from the." to "Number of SOP Instances in Series"

ImagingStudy.series.instance.sopclass Alias to camelCase

ImagingStudy.series.instance.url change "WADO-RS resource where the instance is available.";  delete comment

ImagingStudy.series.instance.attachment A FHIR resource representing the content of this instance.

Comments A FHIR resource might not represent the complete content of the instance.  An example of FHIR resources representing DICOM instances include the ImagingObjectSelection resource (representing a Key Object Selection Document). Representation of DICOM images using the FHIR Media resource might not be full fidelity (e.g., limited pixel dynamic range, JPEG compression, etc.)

Navigation to profiles from the FHIR home page requires knowledge of the resource that the profile primarily relates to.  E.g., consent directive is accessible by going to contract > conformance package > consent directive and then select consent directive again.

Suggest to create a similar page as the Resource page that is accessible from the home page that lists all profiles in alphabetical order to ease access.

Resouce pages indicate the workgroup responsible for cultivating the resource.  It would be hepful to have a page that lists for each workgroup the resources and profiles that they are responsible for cultivating.

I'm trying to understand ValueSet.compose. In the FHIR ValueSets there's a value set called "http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/nutritionorder-status-notcanceled". (I found it in the downloads valuesets.xml)

It says it contains all codes from "http://hl7.org/fhir/nutrition-order-status" except "cancelled". The way this value set does this, is:
<compose>
    <exclude>
        <system value="http://hl7.org/fhir/nutrition-order-status"/>
        <concept><code value="cancelled"/></concept>
    </exclude>
</compose>

I would have expected:
<compose>
    <include><system value="http://hl7.org/fhir/nutrition-order-status"/></include>
    <exclude>
        <system value="http://hl7.org/fhir/nutrition-order-status"/>
        <concept><code value="cancelled"/></concept>
    </exclude>
</compose>

Is the value set incorrect, or my expectation? If my expectation is wrong then exclude seems to behave differently from include. Include only includes what it states, but exclude then includes everything except what excluded.

Consider ValueSet.compose.import. This is for importing a value set. Suppose I ask for an expansion on a value set that imports another. How does one get the expansion for the import?

Can I assume the URI points to a FHIR ValueSet or can it be any format? Can I assume that the uri already asks for $expand? Could the uri be relative to my own server or may I assume absolute paths? Could the uri be a search rather than a specific value set? Could the uri be tied into a specific version (/ValueSet/1/_history/3) in which case I wonder if there is a missing uri pattern for expansions on history of a value set. Do include/exclude also operate on the imported value set(s), or only on code system?

What do you do when there's a circular reference in imports? HTTP 413 Request Entity Too Large? HTTP 500?

How do I even detect a circular reference when I ask the expansion for the import. When I ask for expansion on a value set it's not really possible to oversee the full chain unless every import is handled in two steps: ask for definition first and only ask for expansion if the result does not import any value set (version) that you have not processed before and hope that the value set does not import some you've already seen and some you have not.

I would like more guidance on what type of URIs to expect and feel that the current situation leaves too much room for error.
Need to be able to record the "date entered" on a Medication Statement
Need to be able to record the "date entered" on a Medication Administration
Need to be able to record the "date entered" on a Medication Dispense
Look at adding the ability to add a note to resources.  For example on a medication statement - "patient says he skipped a dose of medication because of polyuria"

summary: OperationDefinitions should render with two tables: inputs & outputs
details: Currently OperationDefinition instances render with a single table of paramters, with a column labeling each as "in" or "out". It would be clearer to render this as two separate tables: an inputs table and an output table. This would be a better match for the way implementers think about "calling" an operation and getting back a response.

summary: Composition.type and Composition.class defintions should be improved according to the improvements made to DocumentReference.
details:
These are the defintions for these in XDS, under the new IHE ITI TF Volume 3. These definitons are being aligned in DocumentReference and DocumentManifest under [#3771]

DocumentReference.class - The class code specifying the high-level use classification of the document type (e.g., Report, Summary, Images, Treatment Plan, Patient Preferences, Workflow).

DocumentReference.type - The type code specifies the precise type of document from the user perspective. It is recommended that the value Set be drawn from a coding scheme providing a fine level of granularity such as LOINC.

change

"The Composition date (mandatory). This is found in Composition.instant, which is when the author wrote the document logically"

to

"The Composition date (mandatory). This is found in Composition.date, which is when the author wrote the document logically"

summary: InstitutionalClaim defines a *item.modifier* property, which clashes with modifierExtension in JSON
details: The extensibility spec declares that modifierExtensions to a FHIR element are delivered with the "modifier" property in JSON. InstitutionalClaim itself defines a "modifier" property on its "item" property, which in JSON will also be named "modifier" and thus creates a conflict.

summary: PUT/POST interactions should have an optional *Accept* header, currently says to not have one
details: The HTTP/REST summary table specifies "N/A" for the "Accept" header on PUT, POST and DELETE operations. These operations however return an OperationOutcome, which should be available as XML or JSON, necessitating the use of an "Accept" header. The table should state that the Accept header on these interactions is optional.

summary: Correction to section 4.20.2 since reliablity is no longer mandatory
details:
in Section 4.20-.2  Change

change "status and reliability (mandatory) - all users of observations SHALL be sure of the status of the observation"

To

"status (mandatory) - all users of observations SHALL be sure of the status of the observation

reliability -  provides an estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value of an observation"

Since reliability is no longer mandatory.

I was using the reference implementation of java for the fhir connectathon 8 last week, and a few issues arrived to use it with the DEV/DST2 server implementations. 

- ResourceAddress: Fixed RegExp to accept characters in id

- ResourceRequest: added location as String parameter/constructor 

- ResourceFormat:  changed to application/xml+fhir , application/json+fhir as required by DSTU2

- ClientUtils.issueResourceRequest: Added LocationHeader to ResourceRequest constructur

- ClientUtils.issueGetFeedRequest: used unmarshalReference instead of unmarshalFeed

- FHIRSimpleClient.create: returns OperationOutcome but location not provided or resource directly returned, fixed with returning an OperationOutcome and providing additional data in a map, maybe the interface should be changed (was also discussed at the cat8 what appropriates return values are)

With this create and update are working, history and search are only working when I adjust XmlParserBase.parseResourceContained and remove one next(xpp), however in that case, the build process of fhir fails around the diagnostricreport:

  [java] Error processing /Users/oliveregger/Documents/workspaceFhirCat8/fhir/trunk/build/publish/diagnosticreport-examples.xml
     [java] at org.hl7.fhir.instance.formats.XmlParserBase.unknownContent(XmlParserBase.java:268)
     [java] at org.hl7

I attached the different patches for the classes, XmlParserBase should be handled with care (see above).

summary: ExtensionDefinition for value sets is applied to code systems
details:
FHIR valuesets contais an extension for the valueset oid and the codesystem oid. However I suspect the extension for the codesystem is not correct. The URI says value set. Example for identifier http://hl7.org/fhir/v3/vs/Confidentiality:

    <f:extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/ExtensionDefinition/valueset-oid">
        <f:valueUri value="urn:oid:2.16.840.1.113883.5.25"/>
    </f:extension>
    <f:system value="http://hl7.org/fhir/v3/Confidentiality"/>

Value set contains incorrect uri for ActCode.

http://hl7.org/fhir/v3/actcode == http://hl7.org/fhir/v3/ActCode

Already checked in fix in svn 3973

There are a number of value sets using "http://nema.org/dicom/dcid" as a system identifier. The page http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/terminologies-systems.html §1.15.1.0.1 seems to point to "http://nema.org/dicom/dicm"

Identifiers of the value sets:

http://nema.org/dicom/vs/dcid
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/dicm-402-roleid
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/instance-availability
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/kos-title
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/security-event-type
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/imaging-modality
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/security-event-sub-type
http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/modality

summary: Code systems marked as case insensitive, but should not be
details:
All code systems below are marked as case insensitive, but really this should be avoided. Codes are not text. Codes are codes. Casing should never ever be irrelevant.

    <ValueSet identifier="http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/questionnaire-question-text-type" system="http://hl7.org/fhir/questionnaire-question-text-type"/>
    <ValueSet identifier="http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/questionnaire-text-type" system="http://hl7.org/fhir/questionnaire-text-type"/>

summary: Mark FHIR code systems case sensitive
details:
As discussed on implementer chat: just like v2 and v3 systems, there should be a mention that FHIR code system are also case sensitive.

Note: please also refer to #5571, for the listing of currently marked case insensitive code systems

summary: Value sets with spaces in codes
details:
As discussed with Grahame. I ran a report over all current value sets and lifted the ones with spaces in their codes as they are undesirable. In some cases it cannot be helped. UCUM may be such as case, but in most cases the respective committees should update. In V2 the story is different. In a number of cases the range of codes indicated ends up being a true codes in FHIR. Also undesirable. Maybe this is an error for the build checks?

<x>
    <ValueSet identifier="http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/ucum-common">
        <concept>
            <f:system xmlns:f="http://hl7.org/fhir" value="http://unitsofmeasure.org"/>
            <f:concept xmlns:f="http://hl7.org/fhir">
                <f:code value="%{Negative Control}"/>
                <f:display value="percent Negative Control"/>
            </f:concept>
            <f:concept xmlns:f="http://hl7.org/fhir">
                <f:code value="{# of calculi}"/>
                <f:display value="# of calculi"/>
            </f:concept>
            <f:concept xmlns:f="http://hl7.org/fhir">
                <f:code value="{# of donor informative markers}"/>
                <f:display value="# of donor informative markers"/>
            </f:concept>
            <f:concept xmlns:f="http://hl7.org/fhir">
                <f:code value="{# of fetuses}"/>
                <f:display value="# of fetuses"/>
            </f:concept>

details:

in questionnaire-sdc-profile-example-LOINC.xml, there are a number of value sets the define codes in the LOINC namespace. They shouldn't, they should include existing LOINC concepts.

A couple of applications I deal with have 'lists' of CarePlans; preconfigured for different conditions (hypertension, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Whilst these CarePlans are editable, the original type of care plan is available and provides useful information. Hence, adding

<type> <!-- 0..1 CodeableConcept Type of Care Plan --> </type>

would be a useful addition to a CarePlan.

This can be implemented as an extension locally, but is such a common concept that I believe it is a candidate for the 80/20 rule.

summary: ValueSet 'identifier' search parameter should have 'uri' type
details: In the ValueSet resource "ValueSet.identifier" element have "uri" type, so matching search parameter should also have "uri" type (now it's type is token).

A humane readable text description of how the slicing works. If there is no discriminator, this is required to be present to provide whatever information is possible about how the slices can be differentiated.

change "humane readable" to "human-readable".

summary: Snapshot view in generated FHIR profiles is not reflecting differential view
details:
Two examples where profiles defines cardinality as 0..1 or 0..0 (with base cardinality 0..*), but resulting snapshot view incorrectly shows cardinality as 0..* in both the generated XML and HTML . This does NOT reflect the correct profile constraints.

profile 1: observation-daf-vitalsigns-dafvitalsigns.profile.xml

               Observation.referenceRange: snap max=* diff max=1

profile 2: observation-daf-smokingstatus-dafsmokingstatus.profile.xml

               Observation.referenceRange: snap max=* diff max=0

Likewise, in both cases, the profiles define Observation.referenceRange with mustSupport="true" but mustSupport=true is not reflected in the snapshot view.

== observation.profile.xml ==     

base resource

<snapshot>        
    <element>
      <path value="Observation.referenceRange"/>
      <short value="Provides guide for interpretation"/>
      <min value="0"/>
      <max value="*"/>
    </element>      
</snapshot>
<differential>
    <element>
      <path value="Observation.referenceRange"/>
      <short value="Provides guide for interpretation"/>     
      <min value="0"/>
      <max value="*"/>
    </element>
</differential>                    
                
== observation-daf-vitalsigns-dafvitalsigns.profile.xml ==

<snapshot>        
  <element>
      <path value="Observation.referenceRange"/>
      <short value="Provides guide for interpretation"/>      
      <min value="0"/>
      <max value="*"/>     <!-- error #1: value should be 1 not * -->
      <!-- error #2: no mustSupport element here -- defaults to mustSupport=false ?? -->
  </element>
</snapshot>

<differential>
  <element>
      <path value="Observation.referenceRange"/>
      <min value="0"/>
      <max value="1"/>
      <type>
        <code value="Element"/>
      </type>
      <mustSupport value="true"/> *** where is mustSupport in the snapshot view!
    </element>
</differential>
OpenAtEnd creates interoperability issues because it enforces ordering.  We should limit where it can be used, or at minimum add language that discourages its uses.

summary: Require isSummary = true if defining a resource or data type element with minOccurs = 1
details: If it has to be present, obviously it's going to be included in summary.  Only question is: How do we know we're looking at a Resource or Data type definition as opposed to a profile?

summary: schematron invariants are not applied to contained resources (bundle, domain resource)
details: Schematron invariants are not applied to contained resources (either in DomainResouce.contained, or Bundle.entry.resource)

summary: There are two overlapping mailbox constructs - remove one
details: The documents page defines an operation called $mailbox on the base endpoint, which clearly overlaps with the /mailbox endpoint defined in http.html.  I think one of the two should be removed.

It seems to me that when people use phrases like FHIR "profiling" or "to create a profile", they actually mean using the full scala of tools available in FHIR to adapt the core to a specific usecase, e.g. creating extensions, restrictions, valuesets, conceptmaps etc, any of the resources we call "conformance resources". 

It is therefore very confusing that there is a Resource called "Profile", which convers only one of these aspects: constraining resources. The conversation therefore has to distinguish between "creating a profile" and "using the Profile Resource", which are not the same.

I propose renaming the current "Profile" resource to "ConstraintDefinition", and use the word "profile" in the colloquial sense of creating a set of coherent conformance resources and publishing them. This would be more or less correspond to a "conformance package" or even an implementation guide.

Text says: "then the application should look for any entry in the bundle where either the entry.id or the entry.link[self] matches the reference URL exactly:"

entry.link[self] refers to our previous use of Atom and should be removed.

Additionally, since the information in entry.link[self] is now spread out over base + type + id it's not clear what a "match" would be. This is explained in the section below the quoted sentence, and in section 6.8.3.4 on http://hl7-fhir.github.io/bundle.html.  It seems these paragraphs should be combined.

summary: Unable to create subset of types for multi-typed elements in profiles
details:
FHIR tooling does not support profiles trying to restrict types for elements defined with a list of possible types and removing one or more of the types from the list.

Example:

Observation (base resource)

Element: Observation.performer

       base type:   Reference(Practitioner | Device | Organization | Patient | RelatedPerson)

Profile: http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/observation-daf-vitalsigns-dafvitalsigns
            observation-daf-vitalsigns-dafvitalsigns.profile.xml

Element: Observation.performer

snapshot type:             Reference(Practitioner|Device|Organization|Patient|RelatedPerson)

Differential type:           Reference(Practitioner|Device|Patient|RelatedPerson)

Note in example that snapshot view type list is not the same as that defined in the differential view for this element. The snapshot view has the default base resource type without reflecting the changes in the differential.
All composite names for FilterOperators are hyphenated except "not in". Suggest to rename to "not-in"

summary: Incorrect filtering on LOINC system in ValueSet?
details: I normally see uppercase terms matching the LOINDB.txt columns as defined in http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/loinc.html, except in http://hl7.org/fhir/vs/observation-methods where the property "Type" is queried. Judging by the comment in the value set one would think that a query on SHORTNAME regex ^LP was intended

summary: Add an explicit specification of the resource identifier
details:
The Reference.reference field doesn't explicitly specify the identifier format. Having it clearly spec'd using a regex would avoid ad-hoc implementations.

This was discussed by Conrad and Grahame on Skype (FHIR Implementers) on Jan 30 9:28pm (Melbourne time)
Lots of jokes about it at the WGM.  Can't we just use "maintained"?  Or perhaps "Custodian"?

summary: Case sensitivity of LOINC filter values unclear
details: There are  couple of value sets with a LOINC filter on SCALE_TYP=DOC. The LOINC_DB only has SCALE_TYP=Doc. I don't see any notion on case sensitivity in http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/loinc.html. Are they supposed to match or are all these value sets in error? Suggest to at least add a note on case sensitivity to the LOINC description

summary: Unclear how to know what filters a given system supports for a given code system
details:
How do I know what code system filter properties are supported by a given system, so I know how to expand a ValueSet/know what I can store at a given server when I'm a third party client?

I'm somewhat puzzled on how to advertise/request what type of filters a server would support.

Also: what's the intention of http://hl7.org/implement/standards/FHIR-Develop/terminology-service.html §1.15.6.3.1? Where does that extension go?

It is unclear why attachment is restricted to a maximum of one. There could be multiple alternate representations which a client could choose from, such as DICOM part 10 files; CDA, HTML, or Bundle of Observations (SR), or FHIR ImagingObjectSelection (KOS), or even multiple JPEG images in various resolutions. This would need multiple attachments.

Consider (1) removing the restriction, (2) providing guidance on use of a single Collection for multiple representations, or (3) including the rationale for why, at most, a single attachment is allowed.

ImagingStudy is missing the pretty obvious element of AE title.

I think it would be useful if a FHIR client happened to be DICOM aware; it could perform queries and retrieves directly.

Alternatively, I could imagine that a conscious decision had been made in "modern" FHIR to provide the DICOM content only through "modern" DICOMweb, and not through DIMSE. If so, it might be useful to include a mention of this.

The WADO-RS link to the image (or series or study) is called "url" in ImagingStudy, but retrieveUrl in ImagingObjectSelection. It would be nice to have a consistent name.

Also, there are several other elements which are common between the two resources. It might make it easier if they were presented in a consistent sequence. Consider patient then uid in ImagingStudy vs. uid then patient in ImagingObjectSelection; or sopClass, uid, aeTitle, and url in ImagingObjectSelection, but a different order, interspersed with other elements, in ImagingStudy.

Instance attachments are allowed for ImagingStudy, but not for ImagingObjectSelection.

I suggest adding attachment to ImagingObjectSelection.study.series.instance, or providing content explaining why this doesn't make sense in FHIR.

summary: Build tooling should check for invalid reference targets in examples
details:
For example http://hl7-fhir.github.io/careplan2-examples.html shows :

<activity> <reference value="Procedure/12345"/> </activity>

but "Procedure" is not a valid target type for CarePlan2.activity. This error could be automatically detected by the build tool.

At present, narrative.status has a data type of "code", but has inspecified conformance and is marked as extensible.  It *should* be marked as "required" - meaning conformance = fixed, isExtensible = false

summary: Warnings about non-used domains not taking Profiles into account
details: When the generator runs, it spits out a bunch of warnings about bindings that aren't used.  However, most of these bindings *are* used - by profiles.  And, in fact, most of the bindings are defined *within* profiles - so in theory the information necessary to determine that they're actually used should be available at this point in the build.  (If not, move the check to a later point within the build where the information is available.)

summary: Add <specdalty> to <Organization> as an optional repeating element
details:
Two applications I am working with apply the concept of <specialty> to Organizations, such as 'dental practice', 'physiotherapy practice' etc.If you want a dental appointment then only the dental practices are listed.

 It could be argued that the list of specialties available at a practice is equal to the list of specialities of the practitioners at the practice, but that's not strictly true. A practitice may want to list only a subset, such as 'GP practice', even though one of the occassionally visit practitioners is a qualified in Paediatrics. Similarly a physician may be employed for only one of their qualifications, such as an Obstetrician and Gynaecologist employed in a Gynaecology practice, or a maxillofacial surgeon who own and runs a dental practice.

An application I am receiving data from has "names" for activies, such as 'running', 'swimming', 'appointment'. When listing a patient's careplan on a small form factor device, such as smart phone, summarising the list of activies to their "names" or "name" and "notes" would be helpful.

This is currently being done as a local extension, but I would be surprised if there were many activities which are not discussed by "name" in the patient/practitioner dialogue.

We have narrative that says "patient is on no medications" when the change list shows they're on a new prescription.  Also, we have a change code of "02" which has a display name of "prescribed" in one place and "cancelled" in another place.  Typo?

Naming system already has "country".  Might be best to stick with that name (could go to state/province/terratory, but not clear that's necessary).  Not sure if we should put this on Conformance or OperationDefinition.

summary: Why is Composition.confidentiality Coding instead of CodeableConcept
details: It's not a fixed binding and translations to multiple coding systems or transitions between coding systems seems to be in-scope.  General guidance is to use CodeableConcept unless you're *certain* multiple codings won't be needed.

summary: OperationOutcome.type should be CodeableConcept rather than Coding
details: Seems legitimate to have a local error code system that is fine-grained plus the general FHIR code system that is less fine-grained.  (Might want to move detail to CodeableConcept.text if we make the change)

summary: scope  and  boundary between device and b/t/o,
details:
created new tracker for follow up on scope  and  boundary between device and b/t/o,


see #3726  

Are Blood/ Donated tissue and organs in scope for Device?  

The Definition in section 5.8 refers to "manufactured thing"  and these are biological products that are not manufactured but harvested.
create UDI examples for devices, Possibly with both use cases of UDI as instance identifier and UDI as type.   Get use cases from Paul.

summary: discuss order of enteral formula elements
details: Review if most important stuff first and if administrationinstructions should be next structure administration elements  ( .routeofAdministration, etc)

currently invariant is ~~"Nutrition Order SHALL contain either Oral Diet , Supplement, or Enteral Formula class"

this is not an exclusive or  but rather the order must contain one or more of the three.  is that the intent?

summary: Procedure should have an explicit element for tracking any devices implanted during the procedure (CCDA)
details: The CCDA procedure activity procedure entry has a slot for tracking an implanted device (see invariant 7751). The FHIR procedure resource does not have an equivalent entry. This could be an extension, but it seems likely that most systems are required to track and report on implantable devices for product recall purposes, and so this is a candidate for inclusion in the core Procedure resource.

summary: add 'observation not done' and 'specimen unsatisfactory'  to dataabsentreason  valueset
details:
add 'observation not done' and 'specimen unsatisfactory'  to dataabsentreason  valueset

Use cases: action negation which applies to act which in this case is the observation  ( vs negation applies to observation.Value here would value concept would  be "not detected")

Justification:  There is "not asked" which is in the context of a questionaire or history.  in the context of PE or procedure need a "didn't do it"

 

'observation not done' maps to SNOMED 373121007^Test not done

'specimen unsatisfactory' maps to  SNOMED 25154007^ Specimen unsatisfactory for evaluation (finding)

summary: Rename Clinical Assessment resource to Clinical Impression resource
details:
The clinical assessment resource name has created confusion.  The resource is intended to be a summation of the clinical assessment process (the "A" in the SOAP process), not the representation of assessment scales such as APGAR, Braden etc.  At the San Antonio 2015 WG meeting Patient Care agreed to rename this resource Clinical Impression.

 

See minutes of the Wednesday Q3 meeting: http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=January_2015_WGM_San_Antonio:_Jan_18_to_Jan_23

summary: Consider choice of code|Reference(Medication) or code|Reference(Medication|Substance)
details: If all you've got is a code for the medication (which is often the case), it seems like overkill to create a medication instance - which will end up being a "contained" resource anyhow.  We shouldn't force implementers to create a complex structure unless there's actually a need to convey complex information.

summary: Move List to Data Collection and Care Plan
details: Lists are used for far more than documents.  Most of them are fundamentally clinical in nature.  Putting it in the "Document" section is going to keep people from seeing them.
That's where the other kinds of orders are

ImagingObjectSelection needs more and better examples.

Need url with proper WADO-RS encoding (Need it escaped so I can get it properly into the spec)

summary: DocumentReference.policyManager - evaluate if this is within the 80%
details:
As is already indicated in the TODO portion of the FHIR specification spreadsheet on DocumentReference, there is a question on if policyManager element is sufficiently defined and within the 80% FHIR principle.

This does not exist in XDS, so from IHE perspective this would not be 80%.

Seems the functionality could be managed through Provenance.policy in a more consistant way.

Recommend to remove.

summary: DocumentReference needs a method for carrying the XDS DocumentEntry.referenceIdList
details:
XDS, since we originally harmonized XDS with FHIR, has added a new element referenceIdList. This is also a queryable element.

This list contains zero or more Identifiers. These Identifiers may be internal or external identifiers, e.g., Identifiers may be Accession Numbers, Order Numbers, Referral Request Identifiers, XDS Workflow Instance Identifiers, etc. The referenceIdList contains Identifiers CXi encoded, as specified in Table 4.2.3.1.7-2.

XDS Document Registry Actors supporting the ReferenceId Option shall preserve this value. When the ReferenceId Option is not declared, the Document Registry shall handle this extra metadata according to the historic rules outlined in Section 4.2.3.1.6 “Extra Metadata Elements”.

summary: DocumentManifest.confidentiality should be evaluated for 80% and usefulness in light of the Base Resource security tags
details:
DocumentManifest.confidentiality exists today. It is not supported by XDS SubmissionSet, as the element doesn't exist there. So the question is if this is an 80% need.

Further the element is 0..1; and thus not suficient to hold HCS.

Most important is that the Base Resource Definition has a mechanism to carry all of the HCS security tags so it is unclear how that would work with DocumentManifest.confidentiality.

Recommend removal of DocumentManifest.confidentiality.

summary: DocumentManifest.supercedes evaluate for use especially in light of normal FHIR resource versioning
details:
There exists in DocumentManifest.supercedes. This is not well described. This does not exist in XDS, as SubmissionSets are not 'replaced'.

Most confusing is how this would be used in light of normal FHIR resource versioning.

Recommend removal.

summary: Use List resource to support XDS folders
details: The List resource seems to carry all the critical characteristics needed for and XDS folder, as is needed in the IHE MHD profile. Add XDS mapping, and identify where XDS Folder.comments and Folder.title would go.

summary: Naming of sub-elements in occurredFollowing and dueTo should be consistement
details: 4 sub-elements in the Condition resource have a similar structure: evidence, location, dueTo and occuredFollowing. The first property of these elements specifies a codeable concept describing the element. For evidence and location, the property is named "code". For dueTo and occurredFollowing, the name of the property is "codeableConcept". Generally, it is not good design to name a property after its type. I propose changing the name of thie properties in dueTo and occurredFollowing from "codeableConcept" to "code". Or better, to give each of these properties a more descriptive name.

summary: Be specific that JSON format must be UTF-8 just like XML
details:
At present, we say, concerning XML: 

XML resources SHALL be exchanged using UTF-8 encoding

We should make the same statement concerning JSON.

summary: Clarify definition of decimal data type
details:
Some problems with the definition of decimal:

- the domain is not rational numbers. it's decimal numbers. The definition needs to be adjusted to as near to "decimal numbers" as will beat Lloyd's tautology reflexes

- in XSD 1.1, decimal is split into 2 parts, with and without precision. Plain decimal is without precision. In FHIR, we simply impose precision over the top, but in XSD 1.1, we would use precisionDecimal. We should explain this

- clearer langauge around the prohibition of exponents
Nowhere wwhere we use integer should allow negative numbers. In fact, where would you use it like that? should integer be constained to positive numbers and 0?

summary: Extension, Type, Element, and Base classes in FHIR Java Ref Imp do NOT extend Object.equals() and cannot be compared
details:
If trying to compare elements and profiles using FHIR java reference implementation, you cannot use equals() to compare many of the instances nor add to Set collection, compare, etc. without creating series of helper methods.

ElementDefinitionMappingComponent, Extension, Type, Element, and Base each don't extend Object.equals() or Object.hashCode() so a comparison must manually check all the possible member fields of those classes. Some sub-classes (e.g. PrimitiveType) extend Object.equals() so client applications and tools may need to keep track of which classes do and do not extend equals().

Recommend to add equals() and hashCode() methods to base classes either org.hl7.fhir.instance.model .Base or org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.Element and override in sub-classes as needed.

Following is just an example and probably overkill since many of the member fields are not needed to test for uniqueness/equality between two instances of the same class.

    /* (non-Javadoc)
     * @see java.lang.Object#equals(java.lang.Object)
     */
    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object obj) {
        return EqualsBuilder.reflectionEquals(this, obj);
    }

    /* (non-Javadoc)
     * @see java.lang.Object#hashCode()
     */
    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
        return HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(this);
    }

summary: Update the ASTM signature purpose with definitions from the ASTM specification
details:
The vocabulary from ASTM 1762 doesn't include the definitions of the terms from the ASTM specification. Thus it is not clear which value to use for which purpose. The short name is not clear.

From ASTM 1762 section 8.2.2

Author’s Signature

—the signature of the primary or sole author of a health information document. There can be only one primary author of a health information document.

Coauthor’s Signature

—the signature of a health information document coauthor. There can be multiple coauthors of a health information document.

Co-participant’s Signature

—the signature of an individual who is a participant in the health information document but is not an author or coauthor. (Example a surgeon who is required by institutional, regulatory, or legal rules to sign an operative report, but who was not involved in the authorship of that report.)

Transcriptionist/Recorder Signature

—the signature of an individual who has transcribed a dictated document or recorded written text into a digital machine readable format.

Verification Signature

—a signature verifying the information contained in a document. (Example a physician is required to countersign a verbal order that has previously been recorded in the medical record by a registered nurse who has carried out the verbal order.)

Validation Signature

—a signature validating a health information document for inclusion in the patient record. (Example a medical student or resident is credentialed to perform history or physical examinations and to write progress notes. The attending physician signs the history and physical examination to validate the entry for inclusion in the patient’s medical record.)

Consent Signature

—the signature of an individual consenting to what is described in a health information document.

Signature Witness Signature

—the signature of a witness to any other signature.

Event Witness Signature

—the signature of a witness to an event. (Example the witness has observed a procedure and is attesting to this fact.)

Identity Witness Signature

—the signature of an individual who has witnessed another individual who is known to them signing a document. (Example the identity witness is a notary public.)

Consent Witness Signature

—the signature of an individual who has witnessed the health care provider counselling a patient.

Interpreter Signature

—the signature of an individual who has translated health care information during an event or the obtaining of consent to a treatment.

Review Signature

— the signature of a person, device, or algorithm that has reviewed or filtered data for inclusion into the patient record. ( Examples: (1) a medical records clerk who scans a document for inclusion in the medical record, enters header information, or catalogues and classifies the data, or a combination thereof; (2) a gateway that receives data from another computer system and interprets that data or changes its format, or both, before entering it into the patient record.)

Source Signature

— the signature of an automated data source. (Examples: (1) the signature for an image that is generated by a device for inclusion in the patient record; (2) the signature for an ECG derived by an ECG system for inclusion in the patient record; (3) the data from a biomedical monitoring device or system that is for inclusion in the patient record.)

Addendum Signature

—the signature on a new amended document of an individual who has corrected, edited, or amended an original health information document. An addendum signature can either be a signature type or a signature sub-type (see 8.1). Any document with an addendum signature shall have a companion document that is the original document with its original, unaltered content, and original signatures. The original document shall be referenced via an attribute in the new document, which contains, for example, the digest of the old document. Whether the original, unaltered, document is always displayed with the addended document is a local matter, but the original, unaltered, document must remain as part of the patient record and be retrievable on demand.

Modification Signature

—the signature on an original document of an individual who has generated a new amended document. This (original) document shall reference the new document via an additional signature purpose. This is the inverse of an addendum signature and provides a pointer from the original to the amended document.

Administrative (Error/Edit) Signature

—the signature of an individual who is certifying that the document is invalidated by an error(s), or is placed in the wrong chart. An administrative (error/edit) signature must include an addendum to the document and therefore shall have an addendum signature sub-type (see 8.1). This signature is reserved for the highest health information system administrative classification, since it is a statement that the entire document is invalidated by the error and that the document should no longer be used for patient care, although for legal reasons the document must remain part of the permanent patient record.

Timestamp Signature

—the signature by an entity or device trusted to provide accurate timestamps. This timestamp might be provided, for example, in the signature time attribute.

summary: Use of Provenance Resource for Reconciliation
details:
How does Provenance Resource really work? 

From the discussion at the F2F, It was recommended we use the Provenance Resource to point to the thing being reconciled by using the target element. So the target will point to the list resource (which in turn will point to the medication resource - in the case of a medication list). The question I have is, will we be able to tell from the list Resource that there is a target element that is referencing it? Stated another way, a reconciliation requirement is when viewing a list you should know whether or not and by whom or when the list was reconciled.

It seems like for any Resource, if we're interesting in using Provenance, we have to query for both the Resource and the Provenance about that Resource. Is this the apporach to take? For Example, query for a list of medications and if we also need to know whether or not that list has been reconciled, we have to also query for the provenance resource whose target is the list itself? 

It was also mentioned that Provenance can be used to point to other things that may not use a List Resource - i.e. care team members (participant?) which is part of the care plan. How would we be able to reconcile the participants if we do not have an ID for the "group" of participants? Same applies to goals and activity in Care Plan. 

Thanks, IHE PCC Tech.
Add 'active' property on practioner resource to be consistent with Patient and Organization. In case a Practitioner was created in error.

summary: To add new datatype for multichannel recording data
details:
1. To introduce a new datatype "SampledDataSet" similar to sequenceSet used in HL7 aECG example. It will be used for multichannel recording data.

The following structure is proposed:

<xs:complexType name="SampledDataSet">
  <xs:sequence>
   <xs:element name="Channel" maxOccurs="unbounded">
    <xs:complexType>
     <xs:sequence>
<!-- Channel coded name (for example from MDC) --> 

     <xs:element name="code" type="CodeableConcept"/>

<!-- Time offset from the beginning of readings measured in milliseconds -->

      <xs:element name="timeOffset" type="decimal"/>

<!-- Sampled data -->
      <xs:element name="sampledData" type="SampledData" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
     </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
   </xs:element>
  </xs:sequence>
 </xs:complexType>

2. To allow a new element valueSampledDataSet of SampledDataSet type for Observation.value.

summary: .identifier - bring consistency to the cardinality and type across resources
details:
This started in a FHIR on C-CDA discussion about Observation and the issue that the identifier property for observation is:

<identifier><!-- 0..1 Identifier Unique Id for this particular observation --></identifier>

whereas in most other clinical resources it is:

<identifier><!-- 0..* Identifier External Ids for this adverse reaction --></identifier>

The use case for 0..* seems well established in the document and CDA world and used by many vendors.

 

Further surveying resources we find that there are only a few where the cardinality has been restricted to at most 1, and there are some where the type of the identifier property is something other than identifier.

The request is:  unless there is some truly compelling reason to do otherwise, make all identifier properties defined as: <identifier><!-- 0..* Identifier External Ids for this adverse reaction --></identifier>

Where there is strong reason for using a type other than identifier, like string or url, we suggest that the property be renamed.

Here is the list of resources of concern to this enhancement request:

MedicationDispense: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/medicationdispense.html

Observation: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/observation.html

DiagnosticReport: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/diagnosticreport.html

DeviceObservationReport: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/deviceobservationreport.html

Location: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/location.html

Substance: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/substance.html

Group: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/substance.html

Supply: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/supply.html

SecurityEvent: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/securityevent.html

Composition: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/composition.html

Message Header: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/messageheader.html

Query: http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/query.html
