summary: Add unknown to the http://hl7.org/fhir/observation-status valueset
details:
As discussed on the listserv in thread http://lists.hl7.org/read/messages?id=266667

When mapping data from some systems into FHIR, there's no way to accurately map Observation.status.

Rather than default to final, it'd be preferable to have some way to indicate that the status is not known, either by making status optional or adding an "unknown" to the valueset. After discussion, the preference was for the "unknown" enum with words of caution saying that it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

summary: Summary: Add unknown to the http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/condition-status.html valueset
details:
When mapping data from some systems into FHIR, there's no way to accurately map Condition.status.

Rather than default to final, it'd be preferable to have some way to indicate that the status is not known, either by making status optional or adding an "unknown" to the valueset. After discussion, the preference was for the "unknown" enum with words of caution saying that it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

This is similar to #5669 for Observation.status.

A discussion on why this is needed for Observation can be found on the listserv at

http://lists.hl7.org/read/messages?id=266667

The same logic that applies to Observation applies to Condition.

CarePlan2 was created on an interim basis to get feedback from implementers.  Based on list server discussion, the recommendation is to do the following:

Keep Goal split out as a separate resource.

Move activity.goal, status and prohibited to simple

Fix activity.detail to refer to only "request" resources

summary: maintaining order within FHIR resources for list items
details:
The notes on the JSON representation for resources outlines that the order within an array SHALL be maintained even though this it is an inherent assumption that with JSON arrays order has meaning.

I think that it would be worthwhile to add an explicit note to the same effect for the XML representation for resources so that there is no confusion over this matter.

summary: Timing datatype does not  allow one to express "with meals"
details:
Timing datatype does not  allow one to express "with meals"

proposal

1)  to change the cardinality on duration and units to 0..1 (with a constraint that units must be present if duration is present

2)  add the codes

1    C    C    Description: meal (from lat. ante cibus)
2    CD    CD    Description: lunch (from lat. cibus diurnus)
3    CM    CM    Description: breakfast (from lat. cibus matutinus)
4    CV    CV    Description: dinner (from lat. cibus vespertinus)


Simply saying repeat.when=C is a sufficiently complete timing spec
There's a constraint on Timing that says "duration SHALL be positive value". But it actually meant "duration SHALL be non-negative value". Fix this, and the technical constraint

summary: add text Instructions for supplement element
details: see attached .pngs

summary: DataElement definition of "definition" is too vague
details: Data Element has no "description" element, it has "definition" instead. Informal discussion indicates that the element should not be renamed to "description" (which would align with all the other conformance resources), but if that's so, the definition doesn't make it clear why - it should be improved.

Flag cardinality is 0..* but it's not clear you would ever have more than one.

Add examples for when more than 1 is appropriate or restrict to only 1.

We've talked about this for ages, but never actually acted on it.  It's starting to become important.  For example, we're pointing people to use Provenance if they want detailed information about the who/what/when/where/why for a record that goes beyond the "key business elements" of the resource.  However, to retrieve the Provenances associated with a resource, we need reverse include functionality.  Suggest the following syntax:

_revinclude=[Resource path that points to this resource]

E.g. Patient?_revinclude=Provenance.target

summary: order of common resource elements not consistent
details: ~~There is no consistency among resources in ordering of elements.   I think it would be nice if  all resources started the same.  like Identifier, subject/patient, practitioner,date,code or something.  I don't know if this affects usability by implementers.  Certainly makes reading the document a little more consistent.  This was brought up in comment #5159 and I'm punting to MnM.

The resources seem like they have some variance in the pattern regarding how patient-entered and patient-reported data is handled.  For example:

1) Observations:  Per a comment on the Observation resource, it sounds like it is within the scope of the FHIR Observation resource to represent Observations of Daily Living (e.g. steps, calories).  I don't see where/how the Observation can convey that it originated from a Patient.  The Observation.performer only supports Practitioner, Device, or Org.  Should it also support Patient?

2) The Questionnaire resource uses explicit elements for both Source (who answered the question) and Author (who recorded the answer)

3) MedicationStatement (vs MedicationPrescription) uses different resources to imply whether the medication was patient-reported or clinically ordered.

4) Immunization has a reported (boolean) element to indicate if it was self-reported

summary: clarify non-version capable server responsibilities for delete
details:
The spec is unclear on the what the responsibilities are for that a server that does not support versioning in response to a delete request. A number of the current descriptions imply versioning capability (eg support of the version history). 

Is it safe for should such a server to actually delete in the forst pace?

summary: remove amended as is USRealm term and make extension once have a definition for it.
details:
remove amended as is USRealm term and make extension once have a definition for it.

Currently being discussed as part of LRI and FR guide in V2 space.  The definition of the concept 'amended' is identical to that of 'corrected' and violates the value set definition.   ( see the value set  ) Since this is a US Realm only concept and there is no single widely accepted definition yet.  I propose removing it from the value set and creating a USRealm extension -essential a flag.  Once a definition can be got.  

See earlier discussion item: #3635

Did the WG consider including administrativeGender in FamilyHistory.relation?

The C-CDA R1.1 entry includes support for both relation and gender.

summary: Request for new security label for when content is removed from a resource for operational reasons
details:
the value set SecurityIntegrityObservationValue has the following codes in it:

 

ABSTREDabstractedSecurity metadata observation values used to indicate the use of a more abstract version of the content, e.g., replacing exact value of an age or date field with a range, or remove the left digits of a credit card number or SSN.AGGRED      aggregatedSecurity metadata observation values used to indicate the use of an algorithmic combination of actual values with the result of an aggregate function, e.g., average, sum, or count in order to limit disclosure of an IT resource (data, information object, service, or system capability) to the minimum necessary. REDACTEDredactedSecurity metadata observation value used to indicate the mechanism by which software systems can filter an IT resource (data, information object, service, or system capability) to remove any portion of the resource that is not authorized to be access, used, or disclosed.
Usage Note: "REDACTED" may be used, per applicable policy, as a flag to indicate to a user or receiver that some portion of an IT resource has filtered and not included in the content accessed or received.

 

If a user asks for a set of FHIR resources in a search, and sets the summary only flag in the request, then I would like to label it accordingly. So information is removed from the resource, like in redacted, but not for the purpose of authorization. I thought abstracted would be usable, but it's something slightly different. 

 

Can we have a security label for summarised to conserve bandwidth? I suppose it's not really a security thing, but it relates so strongly to the existing codes that I think it's a reasonable addition.

 

Discussion:

* the requester knows that they are asking for a summary, though it may not necessarily be a summary that they receive in return (servers are not required to return summaries when asked to). But it's also true that clients are not necessarily well coordinated systems internally, and it's possible that a client could accidentally try to perform an update based upon the summary (different people write different bits, etc). In this case, the server can look at the tags, and see that they are performing an updated against a summary, and act appropriately (reject it, or process just the summary bits). That's why I like to tag summary resources.

* The definitions of each of those possibly relevant codes gave me heartburn:

** abstracted: Security metadata observation values used to indicate the use of a more abstract version of the content, e.g., replacing exact value of an age or date field with a range, or remove the left digits of a credit card number or SSN.

*** no data is replaced. it's just removed.

** aggregated: Security metadata observation values used to indicate the use of an algorithmic combination of actual values with the result of an aggregate function, e.g., average, sum, or count in order to limit disclosure of an IT resource (data, information object, service, or system capability) to the minimum necessary.

*** there's no algorithmic combination; data is just removed from individual resources selectively

** redacted: Security metadata observation value used to indicate the mechanism by which software systems can filter an IT resource (data, information object, service, or system capability) to remove any portion of the resource that is not authorized to be access, used, or disclosed. Usage Note: "REDACTED" may be used, per applicable policy, as a flag to indicate to a user or receiver that some portion of an IT resource has filtered and not included in the content accessed or received

*** this is what happens - filtering a resource. But not for the reason stated. It's what I'm using currently. An alternative approach would be to extended the definition a little to allow it for reduction of bandwidth purposes.

* These resources were added through harmoniation. the Harmonization proposal does not provide any evidence of the provenance of the codes before that.

summary: Medication should be required in MedicationStatement
details: Medication is 0..1.  It is not clear what a medication statement would mean without an identified Medication. Cardinality should be changed to 1..1

Clinical assessments may occur over a significant span of time. Currently the only time information is the ClinicalAssessment.date. Please change this to a Period, to represent the beginning and end times of the assessment. This is needed for mapping the Quality Data Model (QDM), requested by CQI WG.

Currently, we have a set of interactions, described in http.html, which update profile, tags and security labels in a Resource's "meta" element. These interactions are special cases since:

* They do not do CRUD on the full resources, but just on it's metadata
* They take the datatype "meta" as body, instead of a resource
* They can modify history too.
* They cannot be used in Transactions, since the body is not a resource
* The normal rest operations (esp DELETE) have no natural meaning on the _meta endpoint (you cannot "DELETE" meta), especially since you normally want to modify/remove parts of the tags/profiles etc in meta.

Therefore it seems to make more sense to turn these interactions into operations, where the Parameters resource can be used to supply and return responses with "Meta" datatypes in the instances. This results in the REST interactions always returning a resource, the ability to include meta operations in a transaction and to others to have a natural way to define operations to do system-wide tag maintenance which are inline with the core-specified instance based operations.

The Order class can't stand alone.  It's a workflow resource that has to point to an "order/request" resource.  For example, DiagnosticOrder, MedicationPrescription, etc.  If the Appointment was going to point to anything, it would be what the Order points to, not Order.  And it's not clear what that something would be.  Referral?

Suggested changes

episodeOfCare -> Current: nothing. Change to: PV1-54, PV1-53

indication -> Current: nothing. Change to: Resources that would commonly referenced at Encounter.indication would be Condition and/or Procedure. These most closely align with DG1/PRB and PR1 respectively.

participant -> Current: nothing. Change to: ROL
        type -> Current: PRT-4-participation. Change to: ROL-3
        period -> Current: nothing. Change to: ROL-5, ROL-6
        individual -> Current: nothing. Change to: ROL-4

period -> Current: nothing. Change to: PV1-44, PV1-45

destination -> Current: nothing. Change to: PV1-37

The search specifcation contains a way to search through all resource types at once:

GET [base]?[parameters] {&_format=[mime-type]}

This operation is problematic for several reasons:

* The operation is hard to implement, since this search would require scanning most of the data of the source system, so is most certainly a search across multiple tables in the server's database
* Since multiple resources may have search parameters with the same name but with a different meaning, the hits may contain false positives.
* It is not clear which usecase this operation tries to cover.

Therefore  I propose to remove this operation from the specification.

MedicationStatement has an element 

wasNotGiven 0..1 boolean True if medication is/was not being taken

The definition shows that 'given' is the wrong word - it should 'taken'. And since it can be either 'is' or 'was', the element name should simply be 'notTaken'

it looks like a copy/paste error from MedicationAdministration

There is no satisfactory way to represent a proposed or recommended encounter. ReferralRequest handles a subset of this, but only when there is a request for different organization or clinician to see a patient. Recommended follow-up appointments cannot be captured by a referral. Nor does Appointment, which only applies when there is an appointment. It is quite common that status values include "proposed" or "requested". Addition of "proposed" status for Encounter would capture when a clinican wants the patient to make an appointment with the current provider or another provider at some future date.

summary: Medication should be required in MedicationAdministration
details: Similar to tracker #5695 for MedicationStatement, medication should be 1..1 in MedicationAdministration. I can't think of a case where there would be an administration without a medication.
Why is subject 0..1 instead of 1..1?  TObservation.subject documentation itself states, "Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about" and I agree.

Many or even most resources in FHIR have a status attribute, and it seems very odd and exceptional that Procedure doesn't. A typical status set applicable to procedure might be (for example only): proposed | planned | in-progress | completed | suspended | aborted. Wouldn't it be a good to know if a procedure was planned, so it wouldn't be planned twice? Or, to know if the procedure was aborted before it was completed?

Current: "While the search mechanism described above is flexible, and easy to implement for simple cases, but is limited in it's ability to express combination queries"

Proposed: "The search mechanism described above is flexible and easy to implement for simple cases, but it is limited in it's ability to express combination queries"

summary: Status values for ProcedureRequest and Procedure
details:
This has to do with the status values on ProcedureRequest and Procedure, in particular the "proposed" status value on ProcedureRequest. The problem is that a clinician proposes a procedure, he or she does not propose a ProcedureRequest. It doesn't parse to have a ProcedureRequest that is "planned" - that's the Procedure. A request is simply made, after which it may be accepted or rejected. So a suitable set of statuses for ProcedureRequest is requested | received | accepted | rejected, while a suitable set of statuses for Procedure is planned | in-progress | completed | suspended | aborted.

Note that Procedure does not currently have a status attribute, so we need a separate discussion on whether it should be added, and if so, whether those status values deal with Procedure like a statement, analogous to MedicationStatement, or whether it should deal with Procedure like an activity, similar to Encounter.

Over 50 resources in FHIR have status attributes. Across the board, they all deal with lifecycle states. Typical value sets for status include terms like pending | review | rejected | error | accepted | cancelled | replaced | aborted | completed | proposed | planned | requested | received | in-progress | suspended | rejected | aborted. Condition.status is an outlier, contaning values related to the type of hypothesis (provisional | working | confirmed | refuted). Please consider renaming this attribute to something other than status.

summary: ProfileUtilities.sortDifferential() incorrectly sorts list if have subcomponents out of order in list
details:
Using ProfileUtilities.generateSnapshot() to create snapshot of derived profile requires the differential elements to be sorted in same order as base resource.

Here's an example where the sorting fails:

Path name of elements in differential for a particular profile

AllergyIntolerance
AllergyIntolerance.recordedDate
...
AllergyIntolerance.lastOccurence
AllergyIntolerance.event
AllergyIntolerance.event.substance
AllergyIntolerance.event.certainty
AllergyIntolerance.event.manifestation
AllergyIntolerance.event.onset
AllergyIntolerance.event.duration
AllergyIntolerance.event.severity
AllergyIntolerance.event.exposureRoute 
AllergyIntolerance.identifier
AllergyIntolerance.comment
AllergyIntolerance.event.description
AllergyIntolerance.event.comment

The last 4 elements are added to end of the differential list.

ProfileUtilities.sortDifferential() sorts the list and returns in this order:

AllergyIntolerance
AllergyIntolerance.identifier
AllergyIntolerance.recordedDate
AllergyIntolerance.recorder
AllergyIntolerance.subject
AllergyIntolerance.substance
AllergyIntolerance.status
AllergyIntolerance.criticality
AllergyIntolerance.type
AllergyIntolerance.category
AllergyIntolerance.lastOccurence
AllergyIntolerance.comment
AllergyIntolerance.event
AllergyIntolerance.event.substance
AllergyIntolerance.event.certainty
AllergyIntolerance.event.manifestation
AllergyIntolerance.event.onset
AllergyIntolerance.event.duration
AllergyIntolerance.event.severity
AllergyIntolerance.event.exposureRoute 
AllergyIntolerance.event.description – this is not in correct order
AllergyIntolerance.event.comment

Wrong order causes ProfileUtilities.generateSnapshot() to generate snapshot with some errors such as mustSupport=true being flagged as false.

Error is here in which the loop stop when it encounters an element with a different prefix; e.g. AllergyIntolerance.identifier in our example and never adds AllergyIntolerance.event.description and AllergyIntolerance.event.comment as a child of AllergyIntolerance.event .

    private int processElementsIntoTree(ElementDefinitionHolder edh, int i, List<ElementDefinition> list) {
        String path = edh.getSelf().getPath();
        final String prefix = path + ".";
        while (i < list.size() && list.get(i).getPath().startsWith(prefix)) {
            ElementDefinitionHolder child = new ElementDefinitionHolder(list.get(i));
            edh.getChildren().add(child);
            i = processElementsIntoTree(child, i+1, list);
        }
        return i;
}

summary: general extension binding in structure is not correct
details:
http://hl7-fhir.github.io/extension-data-absent-reason.html
[10:53:10 PM] Lloyd McKenzie: Binding says "fixed" but  the structure diagram it says" extensible" there

Now:

client: The application acts as a server for this resource.

server: The application acts as a client for this resource.

 

Should be the other way around.

Although the URI and related standards prescribe encoding the "query" part of the URL, both Grahame's and my server accept unencoded queries. This is nice when running Fiddler, and you want to enter the search strings manually. However, this has confused developers on whether you *need to* accept such unencoded url queries. I think that it's quite clear that the uri syntax mandates this, but shall we add a note to avoid confusion?

summary: Add "proposed" status to the Appointment resource
details: Appointments, when first created, should be in a "proposed" state. The definition of "pending" seems to be further along the lifecycle (defined as "some or all of the participant(s) have not finalized their acceptance of the appointment request"). See tracker #5702 for background discussion.

Not all systems will necessarily have a record of when the answers were recorded or last updated.  This element doesn't meet the criteria of "essential to the interpretation of the resource instance".

summary: Need to have an association to the Patient
details: Need to know who/what the body site is part of.  What makes this a resource is that it's subject-specific.

summary: FHIR tooling does not check for invalid element references in profiles
details:
A derived profile on patient is referring to elements that DO NOT exist in the base resource then tries to add extensions to these elements.

This is not allowed with respect to FHIR DSTU spec but not caught in the FHIR Publish tooling. Additional validation for this case needs to be added when validating profile spreadsheets.

See build\source\patient\patient-hspc-profile-spreadsheet.xml

http://hl7-fhir.github.io/patient-hspc-hspcpatient.html

Element name
Patient.nationality
Patient.nationality.extension
Patient.citizenship
Patient.citizenship.extension

summary: DiagnosticOrder.status  should be marked as a modifier element
details: DiagnosticOrder.status  should be marked as a modifier element - this was missed in the original design, and picked up in a review of all status elements

summary: DocumentManifest.supercedes  should not be marked as a modifier
details: DocumentManifest.supercedes should not be marked as a modifier. Important is not the same as a modifier, and it doesn't actually modify the element/resource that contains it.

summary: MedicationAdministration.status should be marked as a modifier
details: MedicationAdministration.status should be marked as a modifier - 'stopped'. Phamacy should review the overlap between this element and MedicationAdministration.wasNotGiven - they seem like they are interelated, and a candidate for rationalisation

summary: MedicationStatement.status should be marked as a modifier
details: MedicationStatement.status should be marked as a modifier - for the status entered-in-error. The status overlap with the element 'notTaken' should also be reviewed

summary: ProcedureRequest.status should be marked as a modifier element
details: ProcedureRequest.status should be marked as a modifier element - picked up by review of status elements.

summary: Encounter Modifier properties need cleaning up - QA review
details: The class property should not be a Modifier element, and the location.status probably should be.

summary: AllergyIntolerance.status and Condition.status don't have any equivalent for entered-in-error
details: AllergyIntolerance.status and Condition.status don't have any equivalent for entered-in-error, and other similar resources consistently do.
DeviceComponent.operationalStatus vs DeviceMetric.operationalState - shouldn't these have the same name?

summary: Fix typos on SearchParameter example page
details: Several places have "searchin" rather than "Searching"

summary: indirect target should be a modifier extension
details: If you have a resting heart-rate observation of 150 bpm with an indirect target of Fetus 1, the presence of the indirect target definitely modifies the interpretation of the resource (healthy fetus vs. patient who's in really bad shape).

summary: What's guidance for use of indirectTarget vs. BodySite?
details: Both could be used for "Fetus" - no significant difference between a tumor vs. a fetus in terms of connection to the Patient and need to track it as an identifiable entity over time.  Given that "bodySite" is core, it should probably be the preferred solution.

summary: remove ccda entry templates profiles from observation
details: Consideration to remove the current CCDA profiles until after Argonaut mapping and reintroduce and review when mapping phase is completed and the Profiling phase begins.

summary: Create an extension to link a Profile on Observation to a DataElement collection
details:
There's a use case where you need to say in a profile on the Observation resource, that the valid set of observations is defined by a collection of data elements. The data elements say, for each code that can go in observation, what other values the properties can have (values, units, etc)

This is clearly not a core use of profile, so it should be an extension. The same extension could be used to link a profile of questionnaire to DataElement.

(disclaimer - a body site resource I saw on a call yesterday does not look like this continuous integration build one--but I assume this is the current one)

It seems that sites have been divided into specific sites, which may have laterality or plane, but no other refinements, and relative sites, which have a richer set of modifiers ("aspect"), but which treat the base concept as a "landmark" from which to navigate rather than as a spatial concept requiring its own modification.

The FHIM has proposed a model in which a site concept has an optional modifier. This modifier could be laterality, but it could also be any of a number of other concepts (some of them are listed in "aspect"; many are not).

Unless we have use cases requiring this distinction, I'd recommend collapsing them, merging laterality and aspect (and plane?), and letting the selected set of properties determine what sort of site specification an instance is. The extra distinction doesn't seem to add value, but it does require that an implementer make a constraining choice.

Нow to transmit the orderer organization in Order?

We have Order.source which could be only Practitioner reference.

What about to allow Organization reference in Order.source?

 

I think allowing Organization as an Order.source is reasonable.  If one lab wants to delegate an order to another lab, that's typically done at the organizational level.  Responsibility isn't attributed to a single lab tech (I don't think).  i'd suggest you raise it as a change request.

Lloyd McKenzie

I think it would be helpful to state explicitly that no ordering semantics are assumed or required on version ids.

In other words it is not assumed that there is an ordering < on version ids for which v1 < v2 <=> version v1 is an earlier version of the resource than version v2.

It might also be useful to be explicit about what equality on version ids means - although the spec says "Both the Version Id and the Last Modified Date change any time the resource changes.", a stronger statement should be made to the effect that the same version id can never be reused for two different versions of the same resource.

summary: Condition should have only one certainty-related element
details: There is an inappropriate overlap between Condition.status and Condition.certainty. The values of status, namely Confirmed, Unconfirmed, and Refuted are really certainties, and they correspond to values in the certainty element, i.e.: Confirmed = Known Present; Unconfirmed = Known possible; Refuted = Known Absent. Having two elements that deal with certainty requires invariants to avoid logical conflicts, such as Refuted and Known Present or Confirmed and Know Absent. The final status value, resolved, is already covered by abatement[x]. So the status element is doing nothing more than repeating and possibly contradicting information found elsewhere in the resource. Condition.status can therefore be eliminated, without loss of information.

summary: Replace AllergyIntolerance.status with certainty and abatement
details: AllergyIntolerance.status is a mixed bag. Three of the values, i.e. "confirmed", "unconfirmed", and "refuted" are certainties (could be renamed with certainty codes like known present, known possible, known absent). The other value, "resolved", deals with a change in the physical state of the patient, and corresponds to the abatement of the allergy. It would make more sense, logically, to split status into two new elements, AllergyIntolerance.certainty and AllergyIntolerance.abatement[x]. This would clear up the status and also bring AllergyIntolerance in line with Condition (allergies are kinds of conditions, so that also makes sense). AllergyIntolerance.status could then be dropped. Eliminating AllergyIntolerance.status also makes sense in a larger context because other resources use "status" quite differently, namely, to represent the business flow or lifecycle of clinical orders and documents. AllergyIntolerance is a significant outlier in this respect.

summary: Missing name not checked for extension defs in derived profiles in tools
details:
According to the extension definition in spec, name field is required (1..1).

http://hl7-fhir.github.io/extensiondefinition.html

The spreadsheet source/patient/patient-uslab-profile-spreadsheet.xml
and corresponding generated XML patient-uslab-uslabphpatient.profile.xml
do not have names for two extensions which I'm told is not valid with respect to the FHIR spec.

<element>
      <path value="Patient.address.extension"/>
      <short value="County/Parish FIPS codes"/>
      <type>
        <code value="Extension"/>
        <profile value="http://hl7.org/fhir/ExtensionDefinition/us-core-county"/>
      </type>

<element>
      <path value="Patient.address.extension.extension"/>
      <short value="Additional Content defined by implementations"/>
      <type>
        <code value="Extension"/>
        <profile value="http://hl7.org/fhir/ExtensionDefinition/iso21090-SC-coding"/>
      </type>

If this is invalid then validation tools for spreadsheets need to reject the profile spreadsheet.

Current text says the following:

"The <code>code</code> element on both Group and Question allows an individual question, a group of questions or even the questionnaire as a whole to be associated with a pre-defined terminology of questions and question groups such as LOINC or SNOMED"

The feeling of the SDC group is that SNOMED CT is not a terribly appropriate terminology for identifying questions or groups of questions - it's not that it can't be used, but we don't want to imply that it's good or even best practice.  So suggest changing to just "such as LOINC"

summary: Explain relationship between Question and Code/DataElement
details:
Questionnaire allows linking a Question to a code (e.g. LOINC) or a DataElement, but provides no guidance on the degree of expected alignment between the text of the question, data type, value set, etc.  Also, it's not made clear whether referencing a code is sufficient or whether the question, data type, etc. should be declared  Propose to add the following language:

"NOTE: Even if standard question definitions are referenced using <code>code</code> or the <code>deReference</code> extension, information such as the question text, data type and value set SHOULD still be declared for the question.  Systems processing the questionnaire may not have access to or support the ability to look up the question definitions from external sources.  If the information is not included in-line within the questionnaire, other systems may not be able to to render or use the Questionnaire.

If an external reference (<code>code</code> or <code>deReference</code> extension) is included along with question information such as question text, data type or value set, it is expected that the content for the question and the referenced definition would be in alignment.  However, FHIR does not dictate what degree of
alignment is required.  E.g. Does the question text need to match exactly?  Is it legitimate for a question to constrain the allowed value set of possible answers?  These rules will need to be established within implementation environments."

These rules are still permissive because not all systems may follow best practice

summary: Provide further clarification about the root group
details:
As designed, the "first" group in a questionnaire corresponds to the questionnaire itself but this isn't made as explicit as it could be in the text.  The language currently reads "The Questionnaire contains one "root" Group, which contains all the content of the questionnaire."

Suggest adding the following:

"This "root" group contains elements that apply to the entire questionnaire - the <code>title</code> for the questionnaire, the <code>concept</code> that represents the meaning of the overall questionnaire (e.g. a code for "family history"), the <code>text</code> to display at the top of the questionnaire, etc.  (In most cases, <code>required</code> would be 'true' and <code>repeats</code> would be false for the root group"

summary: Point from Questionnaire to the common extensions
details: There are a large number of common extensions defined both for questionnaire and for elements that are relevant to this resource.  We should include a pointer to these in the description of the resource to draw implementers attention to them.

summary: Explain mapping from AnswerFormat to data type
details: Some of the codes in AnswerFormat - the value set for Questionnaire.group.question.type don't correspond to a FHIR data type (e.g. "choice", "open-choice").  We need to add text that explains how those codes map to a FHIR data type to use in the corresponding QuestionnaireAnswer instance.

summary: Move "attachment" extensions to generic element profile
details: There are two extensions in the common questionaire extensions list that can apply to other types of elements (in profiles, extensions and data elements).  Therefore these extensions should move to the element-extensions profile.

summary: SDC-specific extensions should be general, but not name-value pair
details: There are extensions defined in the SDC profile that allow capturing things like help text, text to display after a group or question, etc.  However, these may be useful outside of the SDC context.  They should be moved to the generic questionnaire extensions profile.  In addition, each of them should be defined as a distinct extension rather than a name-value pair as they are now.  This will reduce the complexity of instances.

We have defined $everything on patient - get all records relating to a patient. We have been asked for the same operation on an encounter too, (by openMRS, which have an encounter centric view of the world)

This might entail the creation of an encounter compartment

summary: Need to support extensions that can appear on both resources & data types
details: Right now, context must either be Resource or Datatype but can't be both.  E.g. "maximum length" which can apply to both ElementDefinitions and Questionnaire questions.

summary: When parsing extension definitions, tooling isn't checking context paths are legal
details: element-extensions-spreadsheet has had paths like "Profile.structure.element.definition" which hasn't been valid in quite a while, but it hasn't been triggering any errors.

summary: Need extensions for capturing formal mapping paths for data elements
details: The SDC project wants to support DEX-style mappings where you can identify the language (XPath, SQL or SPARQL) as well as a formal mapping syntax, rather than just a "human readable" mapping as we have now.  Should define this such that it can be used on both DataElement as well as ElementDefinition.

summary: Groups have no validity range information, either at the group level, or membership level
details:
There is no capability to define the date ranges that members are a part of the group (or the period of time that the group is available for)

Suggest the member field be changed to a sub-component called groupMember which contains member and period.

Also should have a status property for the group (active, inactive). or just a flag

Four specific elements should be considered: (1) multiple birth indicator, (2) birth order (for multiple births), (3) mother's maiden name, (4) Vaccine program and (5) reason for non-compliance with vaccine program. Items 1, 2, and 3 are used by immunization registries to identify patients (especially infants) for whom limited information was available from the hospital dischage - to match these patients when reports are sent from a pediatrician's office. Items 4 and 5 are used to identify if the vaccine given is part of a special guarantee program (e.g., Vaccines for Children - VFC) and also why the patient who is eligible received provate stock or why a VFC vaccine was given to a patient who does not qualify for the program.

Essentially the problem is, that the $translate operation does not allow me to supply dependsOn parameters to further specialize the translation, even though this could be present in the concept map.

In the Device Clinical Bridge use case, a medical device that measures something like Hemoglobin in arterial blood might produce a measure in mass / unit volume, or moles / unit volume.  The code for the concept in the source vocabulary (IEEE) is something like MDC_CONC_HB_ART, with a units of any of the following:

MDC_DIM_G_PER_DL

MDC_DIM_G_PER_L

MDC_DIM_MILLI_MOLE_PER_L

The mapping depends on the IEEE Units of Measure code.  If a or b, then it becomes one LOINC code (30313-1), if c, then another (75928-2).

So, in the translate operation, the dependsOn in parameter would be a composite (Tuple) in the form uri$codeSystem|code  to specify that the dependency value for uri was set to codeSystem|code. 

In that way, I could ask for a translation from IEEE to LIONC in the device clinical bridge as follows:

[endpoint]$translate?coding=IEEE|MDC_CONC_HB_ART&dependsOn=urn:hl7-org:v2xml#OBX.6.CONTENT$IEEE|MDC_DIM_G_PER_DL

And get back a response telling me to use code 30313-1 from LOINC.

This same challenge can appear in mapping from RxNORM to NDC, ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, and ICD-9 or ICD-10 to SNOMED-CT (or vice versa), where a direct mapping could be made if the dependencies were specified, but no single mapping would be possible if one of the values is not specified.

Without dependsOn, I see no way to use the translate operation for anything but the most basic mapping.

summary: Clarification of Patient Animal Species and Breed
details:
Actual usage of the two fields species and breed are often not precisely that.  This is currently well captured in the definitions of these elements in the Animal class.  I suggest one additonal word "taxonomic" in species. Some additional wording in comments would enhance the utility of the species/breed pair.  I have tried to come up with a better name for "breed" but on reflection, the species/breed binomial is so well ingrained that the naming should stand and just be explained more completely.

Species Definition: Identifies the high level taxonomic categorization of the kind of animal.

Comments:

Species:  If the patient is non-human, at least a species SHALL be specified. Species SHALL be a widely recognised taxonomic classification.  It may or may not be Linnaean taxonomy and may or may not be at the level of species. If the level is finer than species--such as a breed code--the code system used SHALL allow inference of the species.  (The common example is that the word "Hereford" does not allow inference of the species Bos taurus, because there is a Hereford pig breed, but the SNOMED code for "Hereford Cattle Breed" does.) 

Breed:  Breed MAY be used to provide further taxonomic or non-taxonomic classification.  It may involve local or proprietary designation--such as commercial strain--and/or additional information such as production type.

summary: DocumentReference needs a place for XDS.sourcePatientInfo and sourcePatientId
details: Need a place for the functionality found in XDS.sourcePatientInfo. That is the patient demographics as known at the time the DocumentReference was created (last updated). This should be a contained Patient resource of 0..1
Please update "Description of Profiles, Differentials, Snapshots, and how the XML and JSON presentations work." with text to describe the different presentations.

summary: SecurityEvent needs a query parameter against SecurityEvent.participant.reference
details: There  are needs for querying for events that are caused (participant) that are identified using FHIR  references.
The Organization resource currently has no summary properties indicated. After discussion with Brian P, suggest we make Name, Type, and Active properties summary properties.

summary: Operations on FhirClient (.NET) are HTTP POST
details: In DSTU 2 FhirClient implmentation, all operations requests are created as HTTP POST. Found in Vocab Connectaton while creating a client to test ValueSet/$expand operation.

The definition of FHIR Name "id" says it is a string that may be a uuid, but uuid is defined to be a URN, which contains colons (":"), but the regex for id does not allow colons: [a-z0-9\-\.]{1,36}.  Is the regex wrong, or is a FHIR id intended to only have the UUID or OID part (not as a URI)?

http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/datatypes.html#id

At present, there is 2 elements on ElementDefinition.binding that interact to control how value sets are bound to elements: conformance, and extensibility. Discussion at the Terminology Services connectathon indicated a strong desire to rationalise this to a single element. Maybe with an extension for the edge case varations on the major three types (must use these codes only, use these codes or other additional codes, or these are example codes)

summary: Need a logical reference instead of a literal reference in Coding.valueset
details:
Discussion at the terminology services connectathon indicated that Coding.valueset should at least allow for a logical reference to a value set by identifier and version, rather than by a direct reference to a value set by it's server location. Of maybe it should only allow a logical reference and not a literal reference. 

This is to maintain continuity as instance data is traded between systems that do not share the same terminology services 

An alternative approach is actually to remove Coding.valueSet alttogether, and define a profile on the AuditEvent resource for recording the circumstances of a choice of code. Coding.valueset is inherently audit information, and this would allow a much richer collection of information about how the coding was done.

summary: Need to be able to do version specific binding in a logical reference
details:
In all 3 places where we allow a logical reference to a value set by it's identify, we need to allow the reference to be version specific (e.g. to ValueSet.identifier and ValueSet.version).

The 3 places are:

* Coding.valueSet (see task 5782)
* ElementDefinition.binding.referenceUri
* ValueSet.compose.import

This means that we need to define either an additional field in all these (ouch) or a URL pattern (ouch) or make valueset.version an absolute URL (ouch). I prefer the second option. 

Also, all operations that have parameters that refer to value sets by their identifier need to support version specific references too.

Note: this is not version specific in terms of a FHIR _history/[vid] api, but in terms of ValueSet.version

summary: ValueSet.compose.import - need to differentiate explicitly between logical and literal references
details:
At pesent, the comments on the definition of ValueSet.compose.import say:

The value set URI is either a logical reference to a defined value set such as a SNOMED CT reference set, or a literal reference to a value set definition (not an expansion). If the reference is a logical one, it may not reference a actual FHIR value set resource; in this case, the referenced definition of a set of coded values needs to be clear about how versions are resolved

At the terminology services connectathon it was suggested that it is necessary to differentiate explicitly between the two, so that intent is clear. 

I'm not sure that it is - the resolution is pretty much, try accessing it literally, and then if that doesn't work, ask your terminlogy server(s) whether they can resolve the reference by ValueSet.identifier. And in some cases - most FHIR value sets - the logical and literal are actually the same

Another resolution to this is to say that the import is always logical

One of the values in the ValueSet.compose.include.filter.operation code list is:

 is-a The specified property of the code has an is-a relationship with the provided value.

but not all code systems are based on subsumption. This should be renamed to "descendentOf". 

However note that the current definition includes self as well, though this hasn't been evident. We should make this explicit and make it 'descendentsAndSelf'

summary: Are there other ways of doing UI hinting than a heirarchy in the expansion
details:
At present, value set expansions are heirarchical. A primary use case for producing heirarchical expansions is for UI support, to provide a categorised picklist. Because of this, there are no semantics associated with the expansion heirarchy by the specification. Also, it doesn't specify any particular method for creating them (though see task 5788) 

This task asks to explore whether there's other ways to create implicit presentation heirarchies, wehil retaining the simplicity of a single flat list for the expansion.

summary: Do we need support for active/inactive in expansions?
details: At present, in a value set expansion, the expansion is a tree of system|code|display|abstract. There's no flag for active/inactive, nor is there explicit support for other code system properties. Should there be? what are the use cases? Comments welcome,...

summary: add profile= parameter to expansion to refer to an expansion profile. Add reference to VSAC expansion profiles as a place holder
details:
There's potentially a long list of input variables to an expansion operation, but many of them are complex, and not very variable. This task proposes to add a new parameter to the operation, 'profile' that refers to an exteranl definition of additional configuration for the expansion. For now, there would be no formal definition of a resource for that profile, just a reference to existing VSAC documentation, with the intent that if there's any emerging consensus about this, we will go on and develop a resource for it a future version of FHIR.

Note that implementations can define such a thing now, but defining it as part of the base operation establishes more consistency

summary: can we be more specific about date and filter parameters on expansion
details:
The value set $expand operation takes 2 parameters:

filter 0..1 string

A text filter that is applied to restrict the codes that are returned (this is useful in a UI context)

date 0..1 dateTime

The date for which the expansion should be generated. Normally, this is the current conditions (which is the default value) but under some circumstances, systems need to generate an expansion as it would have been in the past. A typical example of this would be where code selection is constrained to the set of codes that were available when the patient was treated, not when the record is being edited. Note that which date is appropriate is a matter for implementation policy.

This task asks
* can we tighten/clarify the definition of date
* do we need to be more specific about how the text filter works, and/or define additional narrower parameters for various kinds of text searching

summary: Improve documentation around value set expansion currency
details:
At present, there's some documenation around managing currency of value set expansions. This needs to be enhanced. Notes from the terminology services connectathon:

Document more explicitly the issues around client re-use and value set currency, and whether expansion parameters close the value set generation ambiguity. Also note this for if a binding refers to an expansion instead of a definition

In order to make it safe to store and distribute expansions, the expansion needs to record the conditions under which it was generated. This includes the parameters explicitly passed to the $expand operation (or equivlanets if that operation is not invoked explicitly) and may also include other knowledge injected from the terminolgoy server. This should be a set of name / value pairs (?should the values just be strings, or is more control called for?)

summary: generate expansions with code system version populated in the build tool
details: This is a follow on to task 5791 - the build tool that publishes the spec shoild fill out and publish the parameters and other information in epansions as much as possible

summary: Rmove note that LOINC should have a version
details:
At present, there is a note in various places through out the specification that a version should be used with LOINC, as some codes have changed definitions in the past. 

In the absence of any identified codes-  and the strong belief from Regenstreif that this not the case - we should remove this note.

summary: Define "all known value sets" magic URI as part of the spec
details: Several existing terminology servers haev implemented a magic value set identifier that automatically imports all the value sets that they know about. Although there's not much point defining such a value set explicitly, or exchanging it, it does have useful benefits on the various operations, and it would be good and useful to define a single magic URI that serves this purpose rather than having it be server specific.

During the terminology services connectathon we looked at Valueset.expansion.identifier. At present this is defined as a Identifier wtih cardinality 0..1 

The connectathon participants believed that the type should be uri, and that it should be a 1..1 - that it should always be populated

Making the type uri instead of Identifier means that the expansion aligns with the rest of the way that value set identification is done, but also might mean that some other uses of value set expansion identification aren't supported. Are there any other than GUID and OID?

summary: Prohibit versionId and lastUpdated for contained resources
details:
Possibly "deleted" too (if it survives)

These elements don't make sense in the context of a contained resource.  Only the root resource gets versioned or independently updated.

summary: should a server be obliged to provide POST based searching
details:
The search section states "Because of the way that some user agents and proxies treat GET and POST requests, in addition to the get based search method above, servers that support search SHALL also support a POST based search:"

This seems a bit onerous. Should the 'SHALL' be a 'SHOULD' ?

summary: allow the client to specify whether the resource should be included in a transaction response
details: According to the spec, when a server processes a transaction, it MAY return the resource in the transaction response. Would there be value in the client (rather than the server) being able to specify whether it wishes the actual resource returned? eg a mobile client likely won't want this (to reduce bandwidth), but a browser based app on a PC may...

<precondition typeCode="PRCN">
<templateId root="2.16.840.1.113883.10.20.22.4.25"/>
<!-- Precondition for Substance Administration template -->

This tag can be found in MedicationAdministration in CDA. What woudl this pre-condition which is a codeable concept map to in FHIR?

Question:

Can server validate logical code system reference when doing PUT. At least for FHIR defined code systyem

Proposal: Add explicit note that a server can, and add a note to the shareable value set that the server SHOULD validate this

summary: Should code system name be a service provider specific identifer?
details: Confusion around this for some participants in the terminology services connectathon - improve the documentation about this by pulling out system UIR management and registration issues to a single section, and referring to it from everywhere that this is relevant

summary: How should display text case be handled on validate - case sensitive or not?
details:
Question: How should display text case be handled on validate - case sensitive (as with CSIRO) or insensitive (Health Intersections)?

Proposal from Terminology services connectathon: this is code system dependent. Clarify that this is so, and clarify for existing described code systems where this is known
Add an extension so that a value set can reference a concept map that is relevant for it's interpretation
Condition stage has a property for assessment, which is currently defined to be a resource reference to Any resource. This seems overly broad. Why not use ClinicalAssessment?

summary: OperationOutput should be removed from ValueSet based Validate operation
details:
In DSTU2, the ValueSet based Validate operation page specifies that

"The outcome is an OperationOutcome with hints, warnings, or errors."

According to Graham and Lloyd, this should be removed. The operation should return a Parameters resource.

summary: Administration of medication to a patient
details: Replace Medication Statement text of 'Administration of medication to a patient' to "Record of medication being taken by a patient"

summary: PreCondition in Medications CDA mapping to FHIR
details:
The Precondition tag in Medication Administration should map to a FHIR resource.

<precondition typeCode="PRCN">
<templateId root="2.16.840.1.113883.10.20.22.4.25"/>

<code>...</code>

<value> ... </value>

</precondition>

The ImagingStudy resource contains 0..* DiagnosticOrder reference(s).

The hierarchical data model one can build is Encounter -> DiagnosticOrder -> ImagingStudy. For this reason it could make sense to allow searching for Imaging Studies that are assoaciated with a given DiagnosticOrder.

This operation is currently not supported and it could be very helpful.

ElementDefinition.binding.reference[x] has a data type of uri|Reference[ValueSet].  This means that if pointing to a value set, the name becomes referenceReference, which is rather ugly.  binding/codesUri or binding/codesReference is better and still appropriately descriptive.  (And shorter too :>)

summary: Search criteria paths should be able to traverse into data types
details:
E.g. DataElement.element.definition

Currently can't resolve.

In extensiondefinition-extensions-spreadsheet.xml, tried to specify the string "What is the date of the patient's birth?" in Example for the question extension.  Get the following error message in the build:

     [java] Error running build: Error Parsing StructureDefinition: 'elementdefinition-extensions': exception parsing pack C:\Users\Lloyd\Documents\SVN\FHIR\build\source\datatypes\elementdefinition-extensions-spreadsheet.xml: Unable to process primitive value provided for Example - unhandled type Extension @ elementdefinition-extensions-spreadsheet.xml, sheet "Extensions", row 3
     [java] Stack Trace saved as C:\Users\Lloyd\Documents\SVN\FHIR\build\fhir-error-dump.txt
     [java] java.lang.Exception: Error Parsing StructureDefinition: 'elementdefinition-extensions': exception parsing pack C:\Users\Lloyd\Documents\SVN\FHIR\build\source\datatypes\elementdefinition-extensions-spreadsheet.xml: Unable to process primitive value provided for Example - unhandled type Extension @ elementdefinition-extensions-spreadsheet.xml, sheet "Extensions", row 3
     [java]     at org.hl7.fhir.definitions.parsers.SourceParser.loadConformancePackages(SourceParser.java:474)

summary: Guidance on redirection in REST spec
details:
Use case:

When I receive a POSTed bundle to insert/update, I'd like to do what's requested and let a client issue a new request to get the response bundle. This enables me to keep smaller chunks in memory and thus let the insert/update have a smaller footprint.

As of HTTP 1.1 the preferred method for redirecting from a POST to a GET is 303. In browser lore HTTP 302 has always been doing that from HTTP 1.0 onwards, even though that was not the HTTP spec.

In terms of support I can ony says that curl (7.37.1) handles 302 and 303 as a redirect where the redirect URL is POSTed (hence incorrectly), while Postman works just fine. It is to be expected that other clients behavior will vary too.

I'm thinking that in part this is due to missing guidance or hints in the REST spec on when to use or expect redirects. If the spec doesn't say its possible it is likely that multiple clients will not be expecting any. Request to add wording in the REST spec that outlines optional usage of redirects in various scenarios

summary: Update documentation about extensions in compartments
details: Add documentation to the spec to indicate that it is at the discretion of the server to include resources in a compartment where the referencing mechanism is an extension.

DataElement has the same need as StructureDefinition to define complex structures of elements and almost all of the same properties apply.  Seeing as we have a distinct data type, we should use it.  This also makes it easier to share extensions between the two of them.

The core team has discussed combining DataElement and StructureDefinition, however has decided to hold off because one is abstract and can define structures that are independent of FHIR and the other is concrete and FHIR-specific.

summary: Rename ElementDefinition.synonym to alias or otherName
details: Sense of SDC participants was that "synonym" conveyed the impression of identical meaning and might influence the interpretation of the semantics of the element (which we wouldn't want to happen).

How doe an implementer decide what to put in the AllergyIntolerence.event.description vs AllergyIntollerance.event.comment?

Also, did you consider giving guidance on how this fits into the narrative?

In "Using Codes in Resources", in section 1.14.0.1 (or 1.21.0.1 in the continuous build) "Controlling the use of Coded Values", the explanation of binding appears under "Complex Coded Data Types", which implies that the notion of binding does not apply to the "Simple Coded Data Type". This is incorrect -- a "code" may be bound.

Lloyd said, "We should probably call out the "Quantity" data type as allowing a binding too, seeing as it's essentially a Coding." But I don't understand that. It's the "code" part of the Quantity that can be bound, and Quantity.code is of type "code". So explaining that the "code" data type can be bound should suffice.

summary: Querying for data elements across Resources, Profiles and extensions
details:
Consider having query that looks across resources, profiles and extensions. For exampe: 

Query element -> retrieve list of resources (or extensions) and profiles where that DE is used:
race -> list of profiles and extensions where race is being used
ethnicity
birth date
zone offset
procedure code -> list of resources, profiles and extensions where race is being used
medication code/name
unit of measure
dose
etc...... 

As numbers of resources, profiles and data elements increase, there is a potential in unnecessary discrepancies in value sets associated with same data elements across profiles, across extensions, or (I guess less likely) across resources.

summary: Clinical Assessment should have a status element
details:
The clinical assessment resource should have a status code. There are 3 status values that immediately come to mind:
- deleted/withdrawn/entered in error - something along these lines where the assessment is not considered valid, but cannot simply be deleted from the record

- in progress - the assessment is not yet complete 

- done. Finished and not expected to change anymore

There may be more, but the resource needs a status element for at least these

summary: There is no way to indicate that a device is no longer available
details:
At present there is no way to say that a device is no longer available - which can happen for a variety of reasons - lost, expired, destroyed, contaminated etc. This would seem to be germane to the essence of a device, since you can't simply delete the resource when the device itself is no longer available. Also, there could be records of devices that were entered in error. 

It would appear that a Device.status element is necessary.

summary: Change FamilyHistory to only include a single person's history
details:
At present, the family history resource includes entries for multiple different individuals. This keeps coming up as a problem in privacy assessments. The initial design only had a single individual entry, but that was changed to a multi-person list. But this was before the List resource existed, Now that it does, there's no reason for the family history resource to be different to the other resources. 

The specific changes are the removal of FamilyHistory.note, FamilyHistory.relation, and moving everything that already exists under FamilyHistory.relation to FamilyHistory

There should be a described way to say that FamilyHistory was not collected for an relation (.e.g. no history available or sought). This probably implies a new element.

In addition with another use case - entered in error - this might mean a status element is appropriate - entered-in-error, unknown, not collected, or collected (?)

summary: Should medication have a status code?
details:
At present there is no 'status' code on Medication. Apparent possible uses:

- entered-in-error
- no longer available (for when Medication resource is used for a formulary)

summary: Inconsistent tense in definition of Procedure
details:
Given that all of the definition of procedure is past tense, the first sentence is misleading: 

An action that is performed on a patient

should be 

An action that was performed on a patient

The Specimen resource has no way to indicate things like

- the specimen was entered in error
- the specimen was lost/destroyed
- the specimen is expired (variation of #2?)

Not clear whether these are core or not.

VisionPrescription would appear to need the same status codes as MedicationPrescription:

active | on-hold | completed | entered-in-error | stopped | superceded | draf

There's no apparent reason why the element called 'status' in every other resource is called 'currentStatus' in this resource. Just because there is statusHistory would not mean that 'status' would become unclear.

in the absence of any particular reason, it should be just 'status'
The element OrderResponse.code is really the status of the order it is a response to. So the element should be renamed to "orderStatus" for purposes of overall consistency.

The definition of EpisodeOfCare.currentStatus.other is "The status is outside one of these values", where one of the these values is: planned, active, onhold, finished, withdrawn.

Given that those values are time-based, and cover the full life-cycle, what status could be outside those values? If some orthogonal status like thing is envisaged, then that would be a separate extension.

The definition of withdrawn is "The episode of care was withdrawn from service..."

The more common word for this concept throughout the other resources, including Encounter, is "cancelled' and that would seem to fit the sentence more naturally as well. If there's a functional reason why 'cancelled' is not appropriate, it's not clear from the definition.

summary: Add additional status for NutritutionOrder for 'draft'
details: There's no status for 'draft' or 'under preparation'. The resource is sufficiently complex that it would appear to be a natural part of the workflow for people to save it and share it while it's being prepared.

summary: Rename ReferralRequest.status.sent to 'requested' and refused to rejected
details: This would be more consistent with other equivalent resources (NutritutionOrder, Supply, Subscription, ProcedureRequest) and seems to have no reduction in clarity of meaning, In fact, it's probably better, since not all workflows will involve 'sending' at at technical level (e.g. in-system request)

Now that IssueType is slated to become a "fixed" binding, it's important that warnings are addressed as well.  The general categories fit fairly well, but a few additional codes are appropriate:

Under "Security":

"suppressed" "Information Suppressed": Some information was not or may not have been returned due to business rules or access permission constraints.  This information may be accessible through alternate processes.

Under "Processing":

"incomplete" "Incomplete Results": Not all data sources typically accessed could be reached so the returned information may not be complete

As a separate high-level category:

"informational" "Informational" A message unrelated to the processing success of the completed operation

Examples of the latter include things like reminders of password expiry, system maintenance times, etc.

summary: Would like List.title and List.comments  to explain what the contents of the List are
details: The HSI (IHE) would like to use List for XDS Folders. These are groupings of DocumentReference resources for some purpose that is described in Title, and Comments. These would be strings and would be searchable.

summary: Would like List status code to track lifecycle of a list
details: The HSI (IHE) would like to use List for XDS Folders. These are groupings of DocumentReference resources for some purpose that is described in Title, and Comments. An XDS Folder goes through a simple lifecycle, so would like to have a lifecycle status field. This would be similar to DocumentReference.status and could reuse that valueset.

The HSI (IHE) would like to use List for XDS Folders. These are groupings of DocumentReference resources for some purpose that is described in Title, and Comments. Thus we need a new code added to the List.code valueset for "Folder".

Order Resource lacks a way to cancel order

One option is to add cancel flag +/- Cancel date to Order

The order fulfiller could accept the cancel ( i.e. before specimen collection for a DiagnosticOrder) and ultimately .OrderResponse would have a status of "cancelled"

The order fulfiller could ignore the cancel ( i.e. after specimen collection for a DiagnosticOrder) and ultimately .OrderResponse would have a status of "completed" or some other status

Other things to clarify:

1) How to change an Order - one possibility is a two step process of Cancel and new Order

2) How would the "replaced" status in OrderResponse be used in this context since is not clear how to use Order resource to request a replace.

In 1.20.2.1.4,

Timing schedules are used for to record

should be

Timing schedules are used to record
Per DAF ballot comment 89: Search Parameters table column 'Paths' is generating all value as 'null'.

summary: Identification of Value Sets Used in a Profile
details:
The DAF ballot received feedback some value sets that were available elsewhere in FHIR (e.g. US Realm).

The DAF team plans to update the DAF ballot to use these shared value sets but would like a way to identify which value sets are used in DAF.

Have there been any discussions to add to IG page, or elsewhere, which value sets are used within a profile?

If the intent of the "duration" profile on Quantity (http://hl7-fhir.github.io/Duration.profile.xml.html) is to standardize the representation of durations as just a "Quantity with rules", then within Timing.repeat the duration element should instead use this duration profile (instead of having Timing.repeat.duration and Timing.repeat.units).

May also expressed as a rate per unit of time such as 100ml per hour

should be

May also be expressed as a rate per unit of time such as 100ml per hour

summary: MedicationAdministration.dosage.rate where no duration is needed
details:
The explanation of MedicationAdministration.dosage.rate says

May also expressed as a rate per unit of time such as 100ml per hour - the duration is then not specified, or is specified in the quantity.

Please clarify how a "ratio" can be used to say, "100ml/hr", especially given the constraint on ratio says

numerator and denominator SHALL both be present, or both be absent

In the case of "100ml/hr" it seems that a Quantity with unit of measure "ml/hr" would be better.

The removal of udi as a specific field has created unresolveable problems for implementers. These manifest in this language:

The UDI may identify an instance of a device uniquely (when the PI(s) include a serial number). In this case the Device,identifier element is used. Or the UDI may just identify the type of the device and the Device.type is then used

In the context this appears, this is a binary distinction being made here: either the UDI identifies an instance of a device uniquely, or it just identifies the type of the device. In practice, though, most UDIs will do neither, and implementers are unable to proceed. 

Nor, while I'm here, is there any information about how a UDI should be represented. Please add as many examples as necessary so that there is no ambiguity about how all UDIs that might be encountered should be represented

summary: Sender and Receiver resource lists should be identical (including order)
details: Receiver is missing Organization and the order of the resources is different.  Alphabetical would be best

summary: "Binding can only be present for coded elements" needs to be updated on DataElement
details: The formal rule has been generalized to support "string".  The description needs to as well.

How do you represent things like "upper", "lower", "deep", "basal", "top", etc. using the new BodySite resource?

Is the expectation that you do that in terminology? It seems inconsistent to have an element for "side" but not an element for this type of qualifier.

How do you address precoordination? Is the expectation that anyone using local codes for "right arm" or "right upper quadrant" "shred" them to the postcoordinated form before using the FHIR service?

summary: add Range datatype to choice of .value{x]
details:
add Range datatype to choice of .value{x]

Use case:  

WBC/HPF is a very common observation, recorded in urine analysis reports and is represented with a value range e.g. 10-20.

Which datatype would be most suitable for encoding this in the value field of the observation resource?  answer  range 

example:

<valueRange> <low> <value value="10" /> <units value="WBC/HPF" /> </low> <high> <value value="20" /> <units value="WBC/HPF" /> </high> </valueRange>

summary: add concepts of Draft and Cancelled to DiagnosticOrder.status value set
details:
add concepts of Draft and Cancelled to DiagnosticOrder.status value set

Draft: the request is in preliminary form prior to being sent

Cancelled: the request has been withdrawn

from FHIR core of review of statuses:

"As for the *Request resources, We think that these should have these common status codes:

·         Proposed: it has been suggested that a request be made
·         Draft: the request is in preliminary form prior to being sent
·         Requested: the request has been submitted to the person or organization chosen to fulfill the request
·         Accepted: the request has been accepted by the person or organization chosen to fulfill the request
·         Rejected: the request has been refused by the person or organization chosen to fulfill the request

·         Suspended: the request has been held

·         Completed: the action described by the request has been completed; the request has been fulfilled

·         Cancelled: the request has been withdrawn
·         Failed: the action described by the request has failed"

 

DO is missing Draft and Cancelled.
When an active goal is closed, it is common to add an 'outcome' - eg was the goal achieved or not. I would suggest a codeableconcept as the most apporpraite datatype. it would be optional.

summary: Proposal to add Patient to Specimen.collector
details:
Recommending that Patient be added as one of the resourced that Specimen.collector can point to to satisfy the use case of patients collecting specimens.

Another way to handle this could be to make Specimen.collector have data type choice (i.e. collector[x]) with one of the data types being CodeableConcept.  The values could be RN, Patient, MA, Phlebotomist, etc.

I propose that Specimen.collection.quantity be changed to Specimen.collection.amount[x] with data type choices of Quantity and CodeableConcept.  We have use cases where specimen is not always a measureable quantity but rather a "fuzzy" quantity.  Things like Scant, Moderate, Large, etc.

When a Bundle is used to contain a transaction, each individual REST interaction within the transaction has its own Entry with a Transaction and TransactionResponse.

Conceptually however, these components are not the transaction, but the individual interactions within a transaction, so:

* Transaction should be renamed to Interaction

* TransactionResponse should be renamed to InteractionResponse

MedicationPrescription.dosageInstruction and MedicationDispense.dosageInstruction both define properties for the schedule describing when the medication should be administered.  The definitions and datatypes are the same, but the names are slightly different:

MedicationPrescription.dosageInstruction.scheduled[x]

MedicationDispense.dosageInstruction.schedule[x]

Note the extra 'd' in the MedicationPrescription property.  These should ideally be consistent with one another, and I'd suggest that schedule[x] (no 'd') is probably the right choice (especially since Medication has a "schedule" property).

summary: Clinical orders should be paired with the thing they are ordering  and certainly not in same group as order and orderresponse
details:
Clinical orders should be paired with the thing they are ordering  and certainly not in same group as order and orderresponse

see http://hl7-fhir.github.io/resourcelist.html

Currently DO is next to DR - IMO nice

PR is grouped with Order and not next to procedure  - IMO not nice

Why?  1) everybody mixes up the Order/orderresponce with the clinical orders  so they need to be separate so no guilt by association.  2) when looking for a procedure or device or lab order looking in the clnical section at the pair ( like a couple)  seems to be more natural to me than orders sitting over here the things you are ordering over there.

In section 1.16.0.2 there is a paragraph describing references resolving inside Bundle:

"then the application should look for any entry in the bundle where either the entry.id or the entry.link[self] matches the reference URL exactly"

But there is no Bundle.entry.link and Bundle.entry.id elements, so paragraph seems outdated.

I think it would be better if $meta-change would be split up into $meta-add and $meta-delete.

$meta-change with a Code parameter for if you want to add(default) or delete meta data is very error-prone.

separate operations for add and delete would be much more clear for the user.

summary: No codes sepcified for in-paramter "mode" in $meta-change
details:
There are no codes specified for the in parameter "mode" in the $meta-change operation.

Possible codes should be something like: 

- "add"
- "delete"

Before you add this please see issue #5866, it might not be necessary.

summary: add comment about ADT processing to valueset
details: Make it explicit that the 'admin-notify' category is for v2 ADT processing...
Some alerts may be tied to a particular encounter.  E.g. positive for a particular bacterial strain or other encounter-specific warnings.

summary: Time/DateTime DataType RegExes Don't Match Descriptions
details:
The time datatype description states: "Seconds may be provided but may also be ignored."  The use of the word "may" would seem to indicate that seconds are optional (especially given that the spec allows them to be ignored).

The regex, however, requires seconds: ([01][0-9]|2[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]:[0-5][0-9](\.[0-9]+)?

When writing examples, the build tools example validator also enforces this constraint (e.g., I tried to write an example with Patient.birthTime as "06:12" and it threw an error).

It looks to me like the DateTime datatype may have the same problem (description implies that seconds are optional, but regex requires them).

Either the descriptions should be clarified or the regexes should be updated to make seconds optional.

summary: DocumentManifest should be able to have Attachment as the content along with the references listed.
details:
Discussion around the change made with [5536] indicate that it was not fully the intended change.

From Paul

The intention in San Antonio was to change, as detailed below, DocumentManifest so that content would be:

content[x] 0..* Reference(DocumentReference|Binary|Media)|Attachment  (I've assumed Binary and Media were there before

This way the manifest is the collection of all documents (loose use of term) and DocumentReference retains its role as a reference not a container.

summary: DocumentManifest should have a request reference to track the request this manifest fulfills
details:
From Paul

We also need a DocumentManifest.request 0..* Reference(Any) so that we can identify the resource which this refers to (if any). For example if I send a PreAuthorization then I need the DocumentManifest to refer to the PreAuthorization. I'm not sure how this is even useful to support referrals, claims etc, without a reference.

Regards
Paul

summary: DocumentReference.content should not be Attachment as it confuses the "Reference" with "Containment"
details:
From Paul

The changes made to DocumentReference [for content using Attachment] confuses the role as a container and forces the implementer which has a file in hand to create a DocumentManifest and a DocumentReference, which is doable just more work for questionable gain.

John Comment: Yet any reference can be included using containment, so use of Attachment or not can result in the same. The advantage of using Attachment is that it nicely groups hash/size/language/mimeType/title.
