summary: Value set should explain how master files are handled
details: Quite a few systems treat drug tables, lab test tables, location tables, etc. as "code tables" because they have codes associated with them and they're referenced via codes.  We should add a section that explains how in FHIR, the "code system" aspect and the details about the medication, lab tests, locations, etc. are handled via separate resources.

summary: Allow For Inclusion of Contextual Links in Headers on individual Resources or Bundle.entry
details:
For a application exposing FHIR resources there is often a need to expose information related to a given resource that is dependant on the actor requesting the resource or the context of the call.

Authorization type information such as whether the calling actor has permissions to update the resource they have requested is related to the resource, but specific to the calling context.

I believe it's highly desirable to separate this kind of information from the actual resource, this allows a system to store or re-distribute the resource as appropriate without worrying about whether they are accidentally distributing inaccurate information that related to the original calling context.

Because of this separation, I believe that it would not be appropriate to put this information in tags / labels as they appear more appropriate for information about the resource that is the same regardless of what actor is accessing it. E.g. the Do Not Inform Patient security label.

I believe that most of these context specific annotations will actually relate to "allowed" or "valid" next operations. For example, ability to edit, require a break of a privacy seal to see more, etc. Because of This I believe it would be good to allow for these context specific annotations to be links that could be followed to take the operation.

 

To support the above, I propose the following changes:

1) Addition of a links HTTP header on read & vread operations

To maintain the separation of the resource and the context specific information I propose that use of the HTTP Link header be standardized as an optional header to be added on the response to read and vread operations as well as any operation that returns a resource rather than a bundle.

This would allow FHIR providers to include this kind of call context dependant information without including it in the core resource.

I don't believe we need to add this capability to any operations returning bundles as there is already the Bundle.link field to contain this type of information.

2) Addition of a links element to Bundle.entry

Operations that return multiple resources in a bundle would need to return this type of call context driven information for each resource. E.g. in the authorization example above, the user may be able to edit some, but not all, of the resources returned. So we need the ability to define links for each entry.

To achieve this I think we need to add a link element as a child of Bundle.entry. This should have the same structure as Bundle.link but would allow for entry specific links.

summary: Include a Recommended Pattern for Exposing Valid Operations on Resources based on Contextual Information
details:
As Noted in the security page, FHIR does not define any security related functionality, but any production FHIR system will require some form of Authorization controls. Where the consumers of the FHIR service may be untrusted (e.g. use from a browser based or mobile application) this authorization must be performed behind the FHIR service. This inherently means that not all actors will be able to perform all operations on any given resource.

Similarly, there may be business rules on the server which mean certain operations are only valid for resources that are in a particular state. For example, it may not be permissible to update a archived observation.

In either case, it is highly desirable that a client application is informed what operations are valid on a given resource for the particular actor / calling context. This allows client applications to render a user interface with appropriate controls. E.g. if a user is not allowed to update a given resource, they should not be shown an edit button.

This is slightly separate from the security labels as this information is highly context dependent. Security labels such as "Do Not Inform Patient" are related to the resource, not which actor. Where as this kind of valid operations information is dependent on the actor and current state of the system.

This applies both for the standard operations and any additional extension operations defined.

Of note, while clients need to know what the valid operations are, it's desirable that clients have no knowledge of why the operation is valid / not valid. This allows a nice separation of concerns where the authorization or business rules can be changed without any changes needed to clients of the API.

The contextual links proposal outlined in 5883 would provide a location to return this type of information. This ticket is intended to add a documented standard for exposing the valid / allowed operation so that it can be implemented in an inter-operable way rather than as a vendor specific extension.

I propose the following approach:

For each resource returned from a read, vread, search, or other operation; each valid instance level operation on that resource is returned as a link associated with the resource. The relation of the link identifies the operation, the URL is the URL to follow to perform that operation.

For type level operations such as create, the same approach is followed with the create operation being returned associated with the search bundle. The conceptual model behind this is that create is an operation performed on the list.

Example: A read of an observation that the user is able to update.

GET /fhir-dstu2/obsevation/5

Would return a HTTP Link header such as:

Link: </fhir-dstu2/obsevation/5>; rel="update", </fhir-dstu2/obsevation/5>; rel="read"

The presence of the update and read links indicate these two operations are valid. The absense of a delete link indicates that delete is not a valid operation for this actor on this resource.


The same approach can (and should in my opinion) be applied to operations, with the operation identifier being the rel.

summary: Contract.binding is the same as the intent of Consent.legal
details: There is now a Contract.binding. This element needs to be harmonized with Contract.legal. Where the Contract.legal element was intended to hold the legally binding form of the contract. Thus there seems to be more than one place to put the legally binding contract.

The Contract.signer is unclear:

1) Now that there is a datatype "Signature" this datatype should be used. The Signature data type was patterned after the original proposal found in Contract. It contains the same elements and more that have been found to be helpful. It also explains the relationship of these elements to the content of the XML-Signature blob. It also clarifies that the blob must be base64 encoded, it can't be a signature as shown in Contract.signer.

2) The Contract.signer is unclear what is being signed.  Presumably the intent of a signature across a contract, is intended to mean a "Digital Signature" across a contract.

2.1) Is there an intention to show 'signature on file' coverage? Meaning that there is some way in the contract resource to show the various places where there is a 'signature on file' managed elsewhere. That this there is a signature on file that is not a digital signature, or is a digital signature managed outside of the Contract resource.

2.2) Is there an intention to show a digital signature across the elements of binding, friendly, legal, or rule? If so, then these signature elements should be upon those elements to show context. Also if so, then there needs to be a clear differentiation between this signature and the signature that would be found in Provenance.

 

Given that there are many outstanding issues, and that the Provenance.signature seems capable of supporting the use-cases above; then I recommend that Contract.signer be eliminated until it can be more clearly explained in the context of these concerns.

Contract.action and Contract.actionReason are defined only as "Action stipulated by this Contract" and "Reason for action stipulated by this Contract".  This is not sufficient definition to understand what would be placed into this element, nor how the element should be used. Further the vocabulary provided does not provide further clarity.

There is further confusion as one interpretation of the action and actionReason overlaps with the Contract.term or Contract.valuedItem. Either there is overlap, which needs to be made more clear. Or these are duplicates and therefore should be minimized.

This fact seems to beg that this is not yet sufficiently defined to be clearly within the FHIR Principles.

summary: Reccomend add "free text SIG" to description of .dosage.text
details: Reccomend add "free text SIG" to description of .dosage.text  This seems like the logical place for this but feel it should be explicitly called out in description.

Invariants have to be declared with a base of the context node on which the xpaths are to be evaluated.  And in the case of these xpaths, that's MedicationStatement, not MedicationStatement.reasonNotGiven or MedicationStatement.reasonForUse[x].  Also, you can't do an exists on reasonForUse[x].  You need to say exists(*[starts-with(local-name(.), 'reasonForUse')])

summary: FHIR specification and build system must be refactored
details:
In this crunch time, many of us have noticed how fragile and inefficient the build system is. The fundamental problem is that everything is one big monolith - it all has to work, or nothing works; the bigger the monolith, the longer it takes. As more groups build profiles, and the scability problems are coming into crisp focus. 

Problem one is that the core points to the profiles. For example, the spreadsheets defining the core resources must be edited to add new profiles. Right there, that kills any chance at modularity. So the first thing we need to do is to make the core independent of the profiles. The specification of the core must be self-contained and inviolable; creating a profile must never change the core. Every place where the core currently points to non-core material, must be eliminated. Non-core can point to the core, but never vice versa. Correcting the direction of references will disentangling of the build system. It will allow folks to build their profiles locally, without recompiling the core. 

The second major piece of this is to disentangle the profiles from one another. DAF shouldn't be delayed because HSPC screws up. Profile build tooling can be designed to be more efficient. Ideally, the core and each set of profiles should have separate sets of documentation.

summary: Restricting references to profiled resources is a gigantic, error-prone productivity sink
details:
It is going to take me forever to go through all the QICore profiles and change all the resource references from something that looks like "Practitioner | Patient | Device | RelatedPerson | Organization" to "Reference(Practitioner){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/practitioner-qicore-qicore-practitioner} |
Reference(Patient){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-qicore-qicore-patient} |Reference(Device){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/device-qicore-qicore-device} |
Reference(RelatedPerson){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/relatedperson-qicore-qicore-relatedperson} |
Reference(Organization){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/organization-qicore-qicore-organization}".That has to be done for every resource reference in every profiled resource. I'm estimating over 140 different places. There has to be a better way.

summary: No way to restrict "Any" resource references to profiled resources
details: Elements like Condition.evidence.detail can reference Any resource. When you build a set of profiles, and you want all references to be only from one profiled resource to another profiled resource, never to an unprofiled core resource, you have a major problem. The only way to manage this currently is to make a huge list of all the profiled resources, each list entry employing the form Reference(Patient){http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/patient-qicore-qicore-patient}, concatenate everything together, and put the whole bloody thing in the profile element. Ain't nobody got time for that!

The question-mark to the right of the hiearchical view of a resource (or profile) is apparently too far away for people to realize that that's what they should click to get an explanation of what the "flags" column means.  I've had several people ask how to figure out what the flags are.  If we made "flags" a link, it'd be obvious how to determine what they are.

summary: Add a search criteria for Bundle.entry

details:
It'd not clear if these are intended to go in Medication.code.text or elsewhere.  (I'd expect that to contain the name of the compound, but not necessarily the instructions)

Simply listing the ingredients often isn't sufficient to describe how the med should be made.

Suggest either adding the documentation for how it's handled or adding an element for this purpose.

summary: "Break the Glass" Method Description in Security Labels Section is Very Limiting
details:
The Security Labels page includes a section on Break the Glass, which is a relatively common pattern. The pattern of including a break the glass header seems to be quite limiting on how applications can handle this approach.

In the systems I have worked with, break the glass is always coupled with some kind of after the fact review of the action by a compliance officer or similar role to prevent abuse. Typically accomplished by any action that breaks the glass triggering an audit alert that is followed up on. This can be accomplished with the described approach.

However, in order for the user to break the glass, they generally need to know something is being hidden from them that they need to break the glass to see. This is obviously a small leak of information but a necessary one to allow this kind of functionality. Without this information, applications have to display a "do you want to break the glass" option regardless of whether there is hidden information.

This kind of pattern can result in users ignoring the break the glass option as much of the time it will have no impact on what information they actually see.

Additionally, to make the compliance review processes efficient, the clinician breaking the glass is often required to enter an explanation of why they require access to the record. This can often allow the review of appropriate actions to be done without involving the clinician. The explanation can provide sufficient context to allow the compliance officer to decide the access was appropriate.

Some systems I've seen go so far as to record a coded reason for breaking the glass to allow trend reporting. This can then be used to identify issues where access rules need to be adjusted as people are having to legitimately break the glass for normal situations rather than exceptional ones.

None of this can really be accomplished with the simple break the glass protocol in the standard.

I would suggest that this be replaced with a pattern based off the valid operations pattern described in 5884. Something along the lines of:

The server decides when Break the Glass is a valid operation. This is implementation specific but generally something to the effect of; there is information the user cannot normally see but is allowed to break the glass to see. If break the glass is a valid operation, a link to the break the glass operation should be returned in the Link header.

To break the glass the user must post a reason for access to the break the glass operation, in turn the user will be given a token. This token can be included in subsequent requests for information in order to retrieve the information the user is able to see with glass broken. Requests without the token will still return only the information the user is able to see without breaking the glass.

details: On pages like http://hl7-fhir.github.io/allergyintolerance-qicore.html, the introduction and notes are no longer appearing. It used to work to have a relative URL in the metadata: introduction =  ../qicore-profile-introduction.xml and notes = ../qicore-profile-notes.xml, but no longer. QICore needs that or else there will be nothing on any of those type of pages.

In the Composition example for a Discharge Summary, several elements do not contain URIs that are supposed to:

In Bundle/entry/resource/Composition/type/coding:

<system value="http://loinc.org"/>

In Bundle/entry/resource/Patient/identifier:

<system value="nhi"/>

In Bundle/entry/resource/AllergyIntolerance/event/manifestation/coding:

<system value="sys"/>

In addition, there are two different URLs specified for SNOMED.  Both redirect to the same place, but there should be one standard one used.  One of them also has a typo (one "/" in "http:/snomed.org").

 

These issues also appear in the JSON examples and in the examples on the main "example" page, but I suspect that they all come from the same source.

summary: allow MedicationStatement.quantity to be either a quantity or range
details:
Given that

A medication statement is not a part of the prescribe->dispense->administer sequence but is a report that such a sequence (or at least a part of it) did take place resulting in a belief that the patient has received a particular medication

it seems the quantity given may sometimes not be known with exactness. We suggest the quantity be allowed to be either a Quantity or a Range. (The name may then need to be changed to "amount" or something similar, to avoid quantityQuantity.)

summary: Clarify boundary between MedicationAdministration and MedicationStatement
details: There's a little lack of clarity around the distinction between an administration record and a statement. E.g. If a nurse administers a medication, but a colleague enters it in the MAR as a workflow management thing, is that an administration? or a statement? How much lack of verification is required before it's a statement not an administration. I think the documentation could be improved

Suggest changing the phrasing of this element to be consistent with that used in the Value Set Definition specification. In that the word "LOCKED" is used to describe when a value set definition is fixed to the version(s) available on a specific date. This would be applied to determine the code system(s) version to be applied to create the expected expansion content. Use of the word "Stability" and the words "Static" and "Dynamic" directly overlap similar, but distinctly different function of Value Set Binding. Recongnizing this the VSD changed the word to "Locked". 

Suggest: 

Definition

If a Locked Date is defined, then the Content Logical Definition must be evaluated using the current version of all referenced code system(s) and value sets as of the Locked Date.

and

Comments

With a defined Locked Date the value set is considered "Locked". Otherwise, the value set may have different expansions as underlying code systems and/or value sets evolve.

summary: Clarify what elements of valueSet constitute the Content Logical Definition
details:
The idea of a computable definition of a value set content based on code system(s) elements and functions is decribed in the HL7 Value Set Definition (VSD) project as the Content Logical Definition (CLD). This phrase is also referenced in FHIR in a couple of places - a good thing - but is not specifically identified as an element. The places it is referenced include: ValueSet.immutable, ValueSet.stableDate.

It is actually unclear what element or elements in valueSet actual align with the CLD. It seems that the ValueSet.compose element is the CLD but since a valueset can be created using an internally defined code system, that specification is also a CLD, so perhaps both ValueSet.define plus ValueSet.compose consitute the CLD. Please clarify.

summary: hostname instead of URL for LOINC
details:
In the Composition example for a Discharge Summary, a reference to LOINC is incorrect.  (On item 5939, I mentioned this, but I copied a good URL into the detail, so it got missed in the fix.)

In Bundle/entry/resource/Composition/type/coding:

<system value="www.loinc.org"/>

summary: Relationship between child concepts and subsumption needs clarification
details:
ValueSets allow their own code systems to be defined including a notion of child concepts. In the documentation (ValueSet.define.concept.concept) it says "Definition: Child Concepts (is-a / contains)"

But, in section 6.21.6 (of http://hl7-fhir.github.io/valueset.html) the following text appears:

If concepts contain other concepts, then the contained concepts are "subsumed" by the containing concept (there is an "is-a" relationship between the codes).

I suggest that use of the term contains could be misleading since it appears, on the surface, to allow for things like part-of relationships to be represented by hierarchy.

1.  Observation.value[x} needs an example binding  - I have tried to accomodate Rob's and Hans' concerns.  by limiting the example binding to 5 SNOMED-
CT Hierarchies which would capture the majority of results and added a comment to the valueset to give context for use with valueCodeableConcept.

 

2.  Summary flags for Observation. applied for Observation. What:  Code,value,  when: applies, issued,   status : status,  who: subject, performer

As part of the deliberation on the Timing data type, FHIR core decided that a medication instruction like "Warfarin Sodium 5 mg tablet by mouth once daily Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Sunday" (from MU tests) was a string that's not part of the Timing data type

Presumably, then, it would go in MedicationPrescription.dosage.text. This raises the question of the relationship between dosage.text and dosage.scheduled - can information be in both? If it's in scheduled, is all of it there and none in text? or nothing new in the text? 

I can see plenty of scope for confusion here

While preparing for the Timing data type change in #3841, I made a survey of systems that do timings. There's some screen shots in \datatypes\timings in svn. One common pattern to deal with this complexity is for a system to assign mnemonics to patterns so that users can pick them by their code. Within an institutions, it's these codes that users refer to across various systems. 

So it would seem appropriate to add a text string or a coding (or even a codeableConcept, though this is probably overkill) to allow the desription to be exchanged as well as the computational form. This is the same pattern we haev with codes, quantity units ,etc - a human and a computer form.

summary: Timing doesn't allow an overall duration
details:
The newly revised Timing data type doesn't allow for a timing specification to have a an overall duration without being tied to a specific date. It has Bounds : Period, but not a duration. There's a set of examples in the asthma care plan for a tapering dose that rely on this, and can't be represented correctly currently (not that they could be in the old way either, they were just wrong there)

It would appear that this is core and should be supported.

note, though, it's impossible to index something like this.

Operations may be invoked using an HTTP GET "If there are no parameters with complex types (including resourcse) to the operation, and the operation is idempotent (see HTTP specification definition of idempotent), the operation may be invoked by performing an HTTP GET operation where all the parameters are appended to the URL in the search portion of the URL (e.g. after the "?"). Servers SHALL support this method of invocation. "

OperationDefinition should therefore indicate whether an operation is idempotent so that the client calling or the server responding knows whether to allow the use of GET.

summary: Additional Questionnaire layout hints - horizontal, autocomplete and select
details:
To assist in better rendering of Questionnaires some additional layout hints would be good.

http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/questionnaire-autocomplete

For use on Questions of type choice, The user input is expected to not present a complete list of entries for this valueset choice, as the list is anticipated to be large. Recommend using an autocomplete style, or popup searching style control. (For use with things like language reference sets)

 

http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/questionnaire-select

For use on Questions of type choice, The user input is suggested to be a combo/dropdown selection list. The valueset list is not expected to be too long, but recommend that a radio list might not be appropriate.

 

http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/questionnaire-horizontal

For use on Questions of type choice, or Groups. The values in the choice (e.g. as radios) are to be displayed horizontally. For Groups, the children of this group should be rendered horizontally, rather than vertically.

With this style of groups, the layout can be controlled to produce flowing content more easily.

summary: unable to summarise extension (wrong count) on DataElement profile
details: Not sure what this means.  If there's an error in the source, then the build should die.  If there isn't an error in the source, it should render correctly . . .

summary: $meta-add/delete should explicitly explain how to call version specific operations
details:
The $meta-add and $meta-delete operations can be invoked on a specific version of a resource, but the page does not explain how to do that.

Per Grahame, the right way is to put the version in the URL, e.g.:

POST http://base/Patient/1/_history/2/$meta-add

We should say this explicitly, since one could also infer that the version could come from the Meta element being submitted.
